Case Name and ID: [On the Matter of the Application of Thomas Scott and James McGregor for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0957)
Petition or Case Title: On the Matter of the Application of Thomas Scott and James McGregor for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
Primary field: On the Matter of the Application of Thomas Scott and James McGregor for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["Scott, Thomas"](hc.pers.002256)|petitioner, bound party|[On the Matter of the Application of Thomas Scott and James McGregor for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0957)
["McGregor, James"](hc.pers.002257)|petitioner, bound party|[On the Matter of the Application of Thomas Scott and James McGregor for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0957)
["McDonald, J. W."](hc.pers.002258)|holding party|[On the Matter of the Application of Thomas Scott and James McGregor for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0957)
["MacFarland, John M."](hc.pers.002259)|petitioner attorney|[On the Matter of the Application of Thomas Scott and James McGregor for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0957)
["Altschuler, Alex"](hc.pers.002260)|petitioner attorney|[On the Matter of the Application of Thomas Scott and James McGregor for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0957)
["Scott, Cunningham R."](hc.pers.002263)|judge|[On the Matter of the Application of Thomas Scott and James McGregor for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0957)
Summary of Proceedings:
The petition filed on 16 December 1898 states that the petitioners, Scott and McGregor, were unlawfully restrained by Sheriff McDonald. It had been alleged that the petitioners committed an assault with intent to wound (stabbing) two individuals (referenced as Jordon and Miller). The case file indicates that the two were granted a preliminary hearing and were bound to appear before the District Court. But, as the petition details, there are no actual records of this trial happening. There is no documentation of the two appearing in court, entering pleas, or being sentenced by a trial court. 
The two were originally brought to court on this charge along with a charge for assault with intent to rob in June 1898. When those charges were brought to court, the Jury found the defendants not guilty. They have been confined in the county jail since that arrest despite the conclusion of the Jury. This petition asserts that the charge at hand (assault with intent to wound) was included in the questions assigned to the Jury in June. The Jury also found the petitioners not guilty on a general question of assault and battery. 
On 26 November 1898, Police Judge Gordon issued two separate orders to Sheriff McDonald to secure McGregor and Scott into the County Jail and keep them until they are “discharged by due course of law.” He notes that they are being held for trial in the District Court for the crime of stabbing with intent to wound on 25 June 1898. Each of their bails were set for $700.00, they were to remain in jail unless bail was posted. The petition submitted on behalf of Scott and McGregor states that the petitioners were last “arrested” around a month ago, which lines up with the date that Police Judge Gordon ordered that McDonald and Scott be held in jail until their trial before the District Court. 
On 16 December 1898, Judge Scott (District Court) ordered that the writ be allowed. Sheriff McDonald and Deputy Sheriff Stryker responded that the parties were being held for trial before the District Court, as ordered by Police Judge Gordon. Judge Scott heard the case on 19 December 1898 and decided that the parties would be remanded to custody, at the cost of the petitioners.

Summary of Proceedings: William Lemke petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his nine-year-old son, Paul Lemke, from the custody of Anna Guthmann, which was granted. The 1920 U.S. federal census indicates that William was a widower and that Paul was Anna's great-nephew (presumably, Anna was the aunt of William's late wife and Paul's late mother). After hearing the evidence, the district court awarded custody of Paul to his father. Anna successfully appealed the case to the state supreme court, which overturned the ruling of the district court and returned Paul to the custody of his great-aunt.

Summary of Proceedings: Hiatt Walton petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his five children from the custody of Etta Caton, superintendent of the Home for Dependent Children, which was granted. Summary of Proceedings: After Henry E. Smith was arrested on the charges of burglary and larceny, his mother Florence petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus. She claimed that Henry was insane and requested that he be reinstitutionalized in Lincoln's insane asylum. Months later, Florence requested that the cause be dismissed, which the Court accepted.

Summary of Proceedings: G. A. Applegate was arrested and jailed for violating a Lincoln, Nebraska city ordinance against "getting and become [sic] drunk." He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the judge ruled that while the city ordinance allowed a person to be jailed if they did not pay their fine, the "part of said Ordinance imposing a sentence for said charge under said Ordinance is illegal and void." Applegate was remanded to the custody of his jailer and the police judge was ordered to set his bail at $200.

Summary of Proceedings: In May 1902, the Umatilla County Circuit Court sentenced R. E. Berry to six years in the Oregon State Penitentiary for "uttering forged evidence of debt." In June 1907, he petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. Berry argued that he had served his time after accounting for a sentencing reduction as stipulated by a state law passed earlier that year. After hearing the evidence, Berry was released.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: On October 8, 1888 in Slaughter County, Washington, C.H. Smith was detained and imprisoned by Justice of the Peace of Slaughter County, James Hart, for the crime of larceny. Smith was sentenced to one year in county jail by Hart, which Smith and his attorney, Richard Osborn, challenged through petitioning for a writ of Habeas Corpus on February 8, 1889. Smith and Osborn stated that the imprisonment of Smith was illegal and unjust as a justice of the peace may only imprison someone if they fail to furnish bonds or as payment of fine or costs. The next day, Judge Thomas Burke ordered the release of Smith.

Summary of Proceedings: John Crawley was arrested and jailed on suspicion of being a fugitive from slavery. William Logan, whose relationship to Crawley is unclear, asserted that Crawley was a free man and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on his behalf, which was granted. Others asserted that Crawley was enslaved by a man named Stephen Gardier. After hearing the evidence, Crawley was released.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: Frank McCartney was being detained at the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was allowed and McCartney released from custody. The hospital superintendent appealed to the state supreme court, which overturned the decision of the lower court. Consequently, the writ was denied and McCartney remanded to the custody of the hospital superintendent.

Summary of Proceedings: George Schriner was jailed in Lancaster County, Nebraska and facing extradition to Morgan County, Colorado to respond to an accusation that he had violated a state ordinance making it "unlawful to sell mortgaged personal property, contrary to the provisions of the mortgage." He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. Schriner contended that the extradition request did not allege that he had committed a crime, only that he had "sold mortgaged property." After hearing the evidence, Schriner was released.

Point(s) of Law Cited: "The Constitution of the United States," Article 1, Section 8, Clause 5. "The Constitution of the United States," Amendment 5.

Repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington (Seattle, WA)
Summary of Proceedings:
Margaret Roy, a subject of Scotland, and her attorney, Ralph S. Pierce, filed the petition to challenge her detainment for the purpose of deportation by the United States immigration office for "being an alien and believed to advocate the overthrow of government, [and who] disbelieved in and who opposed organized government". 
The primary claim for her release was that her detainment was due to a failure to provide her due process. She claimed that her fifth amendment rights were violated. Her claim referred to the answers she provided to an immigration hearing after her arrest in July 1918 (warrant issued June 24) where she admitted that she was a member of the IWW and believed “in mass action and organization,” but denied taking any actual actions. Further, her petition claimed that the evidence against her was based solely on IWW literature that was not actually in her possession at her arrest. Further still, she claimed that the government refused to even turn over the transcript of the hearing or the evidence they attached to it to enable her defence.
The judge approved her writ and demanded that the US government appear to demonstrate its cause for holding her.
In February 1919, the government did appear and provide the transcript of the hearing and the evidence against Roy. The judge ruled that her detainment was lawful and could continue. Presumably, she was deported afterward, but there is no evidence to be certain.
In March 1919, the government of the United States requested that the previously introduced evidence of Roy's hearing and IWW literature be removed from the case file and letters signed by Roy's lawyer agree to that removal.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Eastern Regional Branch (Cheney, WA)
Summary of Proceedings:
On November 28, 1877, Joseph Wells filed to retrieve custody of his minor wife, Matty, from her mother and step-father, Martha and William Church. Joseph alleged that on June 26 Martha and William had "forcibly" kidnapped Matty and that William did so in order to "violate her chastity." William and Martha claimed that Matty came to their home willingly and was staying out of her own desire. In response, Joseph denied their claims and stated that the defendants threatened to kill him if he attempted to speak to Matty. 

While the judge's decision in the case is missing from the file, it appears as though Matty returned to live with Joseph from an 1880 census record.

Summary of Proceedings: Walter Scott, an employee of the Tabitha Home, and Jennie Adams, a long-term resident there, eloped in early October 1910. Scott petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in order to establish custody of Adams, which was granted. At the same time, a case to annul their marriage on the grounds that Adams was developmentally disabled and unable to give her consent was also before the court. While the annulment and habeas corpus proceedings were pending, Adams was placed into the temporary custody of one A. A. H. Mayer. Ultimately, the court annulled the marriage between Scott and Adams but also allowed Scott's writ. The result was that although Adams was released from the custody of the Tabitha Home, Scott had no legal authority to assert custody over her.

Summary of Proceedings: Leroy Allison was being detained at the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane on the authority of a warrant issued by the commissioners of insanity for Cass County, Nebraska. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, it was found that the commissioners had neglected to impose a sentence on Allison. The writ was allowed and Allison released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Samuel W. Smith accused a group of five men of shooting at him and his dog. Of the five, only Joseph Didier was arrested, charged with assault with attempt to kill, and jailed. The justice of the peace set bail at $500, which Didier did not pay. Citing several procedural irregularities, he petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Didier was released.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: Dolly petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to secure her release from John Young, which was granted. Dolly accused John of assaulting and kidnapping her in St. Louis and then removing her to the Northwest Territory where he enslaved her for six months. Young pleaded not guilty and paid a recognizance agreeing that he would not remove Dolly from the court's jurisdiction. Her fate is unknown.

Site(s) of Significance: Samish in Skagit County, Washington Territory
Summary of Proceedings: Nicolas Brown filed for a writ of Habes corpus on behalf of his sons, Alexander, aged 4 , and George, aged 2. He alleges that his wife, Olive, took their sons Alexander and George and left the city of Seattle “without his consent and without any provocation or cause whatsoever”. Nicolas claims that he should have custody over the children as he is better able to educate and support the said infants than their mother. Though a writ was issued, the petitioner’s attorney motioned for the cause be dismissed, and the outcome of the case remains unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Leroy Smith is arrested for possession of cocaine leaves in Arizona, fined $100, and is sent from Santa Fe, New Mexico, to a penitentiary at McNeil Island, Washington under the custody of warden O. P. Halligan. Smith then petitions for habeas, stating that his imprisonment and restraint by O. P. Halligan is unconstitutional. Outcome is unknown.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: Katie Broderick petitioned on behalf of Thomas Broderick for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Thomas was unlawfully detained by the Superintendent of the Nebraska Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE), L. J. Abbott. Judge Holmes granted the petition and the writ was delivered to Abbott, but the events after are unknown. Four years later in 1900, the court ordered that the cause be dismissed and stricken from the docket. Fate of bound party is unknown.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: Samuel Slaughter was taken into custody in St. Louis on 4 November 1854 and was accused of being a runaway slave and the city jailer is ordered in the Commitment document to hold him until his owner (a James King it appears) returns to collect him. It is claimed in the petition that he was, in fact, a freeman and was being imprisoned without just cause. The petition was granted on the 23rd of November. No more information on whether the case proceeded further.

["Dake, Charles E."](hc.pers.002230)|respondent, holding party|[In the Matter of the application of George H. Place on Behalf of his two minor children Howard D. Place and Zella V. Place for a writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0942)
Summary of Proceedings:
George H Place is trying to regain custody of his children, Zella V. Place and Howard D. Place from Mary A. and Charles E. Dake. Place alleges that the Dakes are not educating his children, moving them from place to place, and have disreputable moral character. Place says that he is married and can provide Zella and Howard and education and take them to church. The writ was allowed but we do not know the outcome of the children's custody. 
Another point: George H. Place seems to be the attorney for a child custory case later in the year- Susan M. Horn.

Summary of Proceedings: J. C. Stewart was arrested and jailed upon suspicion of being a fugitive from justice from Ohio. His attorney, John Woerner, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on his behalf, which was granted. Stewart's jailor, Gabriel Darlington, responded that Stewart had already been released on the order of his arresting officer, George Manning.

Summary of Proceedings: Charles Willard was accused of embezzlement in Michigan. He fled to Nebraska, where he was arrested on an extradition warrant. Willard petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was denied and Willard remanded to the custody of his jailer. He appealed to the state supreme court, which upheld the decision of the lower court.

Summary of Proceedings: Lem You held the three bound parties in addition to 40-50 other Chinese women, all of whom he intended to sell. Wah Kim claimed that he was wrongfully imprisoning these three girls and filed a habeas petition on their behalf. Writ was granted for girls to be released "forthwith." You denied every allegation, even denying that the girls concerned are those that Wah Lee claims. He claimed that the girls were in Omaha for the Exposition to show Chinese customs. Witnesses were called. It appears that the three girls were placed into the custody of Sheriff and designated to the care of a Dr. Wycoff. Unknown final result.

Summary of Proceedings: In 1903, Charles "Chick" Houghton was arrested in Multnomah County, Oregon, convicted of robbery, and sentenced to five years at the state penitentiary. In 1906, Houghton was granted "conditional clemency," or parole, by the governor and released from prison early with the understanding that he would be returned to finish his sentence if convicted of any crime. He was then arrested again in Multnomah County, convicted of larceny, and returned to the state penitentiary. Houghton appealed this decision to the state supreme court and then filed a writ of habeas corpus in the Marion County Circuit Court, which was granted. Houghton argued that his detention was illegitimate since his conviction was under appeal. After hearing the evidence, the Circuit Court dismissed Houghton's petition and remanded him to the custody of the state penitentiary. Houghton immediately appealed this decision to the state supreme court, too. In early 1907, the state supreme court upheld the lower court's ruling.

<airtable:mention id="menE9omj8ZKjM9DZ4">@Cory Young</airtable:mention> can you look at this case? the Henrys don't actually have Anson, though they are named as defendants; for that reason, I'm not sure they should be labeled as the holding parties; it turns out Hammand is the one with Anson in his custody, as he bought Anson from the Henrys...I'm wondering if Hammand is the holding party and the Henrys are kidnappers as case role; do you think this would correspond to other freedom suits?

<airtable:mention id="menZImXcrAYDydFL5">@Katrina Jagodinsky</airtable:mention> I would agree that Hammond is the holding party and that Mitchell and Russell are kidnappers in this case. But I don't believe it's because Hammond purchased Anson; I'm fairly sure he was the deputy sheriff acting as jailer. Hammond appears as the holding party in a few other of the Missouri cases. Plus, there's this incredibly problematic law enforcement webpage claiming he was killed in 1836 (https://www.odmp.org/officer/5990-deputy-sheriff-george-hammond). 

As for other freedom suits, I think we should distinguish between freedom suits, fugitive slave suits, and kidnapping suits. In kidnapping suits, the holding party is often going to be the kidnappers, although this suit shows that kidnappers occasionally deposited the people they seized with third parties. In freedom suits that don't involve kidnappers, the holding party is most likely going to be the enslaver. Is this helpful?

P.S. It occurs to me that we don't actually have the habeas petition for this case. We have the petition for a writ of trespass/assault/false imprisonment, and we have the writ of habeas corpus, but we don't have the petition for the writ of habeas corpus. Should we assume that William Clark supplied that petition, too?

<airtable:mention id="menHEbipq3ZBSbExy">@Cory Young</airtable:mention> this reading makes more sense to me; let's label Hammond as the holding party and jailer, while we label the Henrys as the kidnappers. I'm not ready to make a general rule, since I think many of these petitions will be idiosyncratic.

There's actually no habeas *petition*, here. Anson's next friend, William Clark, did not ask for the writ, but rather for five hundred dollars on a bill of trespass and assault. The judge appears to have issued a writ of habeas corpus of his own accord in order to proceed with the fact finding.

Summary of Proceedings:
Yellow Sun, Little Wolf, Horse Driver, and Blue Hawk petition for a writ of Habeas Corpus and Judge George Lake releases them on bail of six thousand dollars. With this agreement Yellow Sun et al. must later then appear in the District Court for Lancaster County. Interested parties, Eagle Chief and Tera-cowah acknowledge themselves as indebted to the State of Nebraska for five thousand dollars. Then, Samuel M. Janney and Jacob M. Troth also acknowledge themselves indebted in the same manner, but for the sum of one thousand dollars. 
(The portion after this comes from the additional sources, and is not in the document utilized for encoding into air table.) 

This allows for all of the petitioners to be released as long as they return to Lancaster for further proceedings in October. Lastly, in October of 1971 Judge Lake releases them without bail and strikes the case, with the provision that if new evidence is available within 28 months they will be tried again. After 28 months passes they are truly free from proceedings.

Summary of Proceedings: Phillis petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in an attempt to retrieve Julia from the custody of Robert Duncan and Sally Adams. Phillis asserted that she was a free woman, that Julia was her daughter, and that Robert and Sally were illegally enslaving her child. Robert and Sally claimed that they purchased Julia from John Sutton and, although they acknowledged Julia's freedom, cast doubts on Phillis' maternity while claiming that Julia wished to remain with them. Julia's fate is unknown.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: On February 12, 1889 William Cohrane, sheriff of King County, Washington Territory, arrested and jailed Joseph Mifford. Two days later Mifford and his attorneys filed a petition for a writ of Habeas Corpus claiming that Mifford's arrest was illegal in that Cochrane acted under no legal authority, gave Mifford no reason for his arrest, and in that Mifford was being held in jail without due process of law. The same day as Mifford filed a petition, Thomas Burke, judge of the third judicial district of Washington Territory, granted said petition. The fate of Mifford and the case is unknown following Burke's order granting Mifford's petition.

Summary of Proceedings: Philip Lowry enlisted in the U.S. Army. He later claimed that he was a minor and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. His father, John Lowry, may have compelled Philip to file the petition. Edwin Sumner claimed that Philip had already deserted from the Jefferson Barracks, although trial notes suggest he had been recovered. Regardless, after hearing the evidence, Philip was released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: John Owen was sentenced to five years in the Nebraska State Penitentiary in 1909 for unspecified reasons. In September 1910, he was granted parole by the governor. Owen found a job and began working, but was imprisoned the following month after the governor rescinded the parole. Owen petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus challenging the rescission, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was denied and Owen remanded to the custody of the penitentiary. He appealed to the state supreme court, which affirmed the decision of the lower court.

Summary of Proceedings: Aubrey Pickard petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Leonard Pickard from Genevieve Pickard and two others, which was granted. Although not specified in the documents, it appears likely that Leonard was Aubrey's son and Genevieve his ex-wife, as the judge had the cause "transferred to Judge Morning to be heard in connection with application to modify divorce decree." After hearing the evidence, Judge Morning dismissed the writ, awarded custody of Leonard to Genevieve, and ordered Aubrey to pay her court costs.

Summary of Proceedings: An unknown party petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to challenge the detention of Catiche, Helen, Julie, and Joseph, which was granted. Alexis Amelin responded that he was an agent for Alexander Scott, a steamboat captain and the enslaver of Catiche, Helen, and Julie. Amelin said he had placed those three in jail while awaiting their hearing. He also claimed that he had never had possession of Joseph, who he believed was enslaved by Pierre Chouteau, Sr. The fate of the four bound parties is unclear.

Summary of Proceedings: Notary Public J. S. Bishop subpoenaed Louis M. Cohn. When Cohn refused to provide information, Bishop charged him with contempt of court and ordered that he be jailed. Cohn petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Sheriff Samuel McClay was depriving him of his liberty. Judge Hall granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Hall remanded Cohn to the custody of McClay. Case files for hc.case.ne.0551 reveal that Cohn appealed this decision to the Supreme Court.

Summary of Proceedings: William was arrested for smoking opium in his home. He was found guilty of smoking opium and sentenced to pay a fine of $40.00 He did not pay the fine and was therefore arrested and sent to jail. They argued that the law in Washington was unconstitutional and therefore, his trial had no basis in law. The petition was granted. The outcome is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and jailed on an unknown crime allegedly committed in Montana, George M. Roe petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus and named James Malone, Henry Hoagland, Samuel McClay, and "Hunt" (first name unknown) as respondents. Judge Frost granted the petition and Malone produced Roe's body in court. After hearing evidence, Frost allowed the writ and judged that Roe be released from police custody. Hunt was unable to be located.

Summary of Proceedings: Found guilty of perjury in 1897 and sentenced to four years hard labor in the Nebraska State Penitentiary, in 1900 Leonard Kephart petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that he was eligible for "commutation for good behavior as provided for by Section 569" of Nebraska's Criminal Code. Therefore, he claimed that warden John H. Hopkins was unlawfully imprisoning him. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After reviewing evidence, Holmes allowed the writ and ordered that Kephart be released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and jailed on an unknown charge, Frank Skipton petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming Sheriff Trompen was depriving him of his liberty. Judge Frost granted the petition. Skipton later amended his petition, which Judge Frost also accepted. After hearing evidence, Judge Frost denied the writ and ordered that Skipton be remanded into custody. Skipton then filed an application to be admitted to bail, which Frost granted and fixed at 500 dollars. It is unknown whether Skipton followed through and posted bail.

Summary of Proceedings: On October 10th, 1887, Thomas S. Brown, G. Geods, George Downing, Chas. Schubard, C. J. Young, and Peter J. Wegener were arrested for disobeying the orders of the master of the American ship Ivanhoe. They were jailed at McNeil Island Penitentiary, and one of their attorneys, Junius Rochester, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on their behalf. The petition was granted, and their case was heard by Judge Richard A. Jones. Judge Jones ruled in favor of the petitioners, and they were discharged from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested on the charge of larceny, Michael J. Corrigan petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that he had been denied his right to a speedy trial and that Sheriff Miller had no authority to jail him. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Holmes remanded Corrigan back into custody. One month later, Corrigan filed a motion for a new trial, which was overruled.

["Lichtenberg, Isaac J.  (Charles Westerfield)"](hc.pers.001838)|judge|[In the Matter of the Application of Alice McKay for a Writ of Habeas Corpus for the Body of Mary McKay Her Infant Daughter](hc.case.wa.0088)
Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: On November 25, 1887, Alice McKay filed a petition for a second writ of Habeas Corpus in King County Third District Court to receive custody of her eight-year-old daughter, Mary, from the custody of John and Della Keevan. Mary had been living with the Keevans for five years, the Sisters of Charity (Sisters of Providence) having placed Mary with them after Alice placed her daughter into the care of the sisters in 1882 while receiving medical treatment. Shortly after, Alice petitioned for custody of Alice. After having her initial writ denied, Alice utilized a different legal strategy in her second writ. Alice argued to Judge Roger Greene that the Keevans were unfit parents for Mary due to their Catholicism and that they were denying her visitation without reason. The Keevans argued that Alice was a drunk, immoral, abusive, and living in adultery with her neighbor Antone, "a dark Italian." Alice countered by claiming that the Keevans were similarly immoral, and that her previous encounters with the law were due to abuse she faced from her now estranged husband, R. G. McKay. Before the court ordered a decision in the case of Mary's custody, Alice and her daughter, Katie, abducted Mary from the Keevans' home the day after Mary's twelfth birthday in 1891. Shortly after, the court ordered Alice to return Mary to the Keevans and Judge Isaac Lichtenberg, who took the case upon the death of Judge Jones, granted custody of Mary to the Keevans. A month after the ruling, Alice and her attorneys filed evidence to the court showing of Della's purchase of alcohol and personal correspondences indicating alcohol abuse. A year after the decision, the Keevans were granted a divorce on account of "mutual abuse."

Encoding Notes: This is a case that has multiple filings; we need to decide how to indicate that the same petitioner filed multiple petitions on the same charge.
Petition Outcome Old: Petition granted: bound party remained in custody

Primary field: In the matter of the application of Mary E. Teller for a writ of Habeas Corpus
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["Teller, Mary E."](hc.pers.000294)|bound party|[In the matter of the application of Mary E. Teller for a writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.wa.0001)
Repository: Washington State Archives, Eastern Regional Branch (Cheney, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: After being charged with the murder of her husband, Mary E. Teller petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in the hopes of either securing release or lowering her bail. The judge granted her writ but only to try the question of bail. He elected not to lower the bail and remanded Teller to the custody of her jailer to await trial.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: The Board of Commissioners for Gosper County, Nebraska found that John Wilken was a dipsomaniac, or alcoholic, and had him admitted to the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane "until cured but not exceeding three years." Wilken petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the judge ruled that while the hospital could admit and detain Wilken, the Board of Commissioners had exceeded their authority in sentencing him for a period of time. The writ was denied and Wilken ordered to be returned to Gosper County to appear a second time before the Board of Commissioners.

Summary of Proceedings: Charged with assault with intent to kill and sentenced to three years hard labor in the Nebraska State Penitentiary, Theodore G. Clark petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against warden John H. Hopkins. Judge Holmes granted the petition. Summary of Proceedings: The Donohue family petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve a boy named Bernard Seward from the custody of the Noonan and Seward families, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was denied and Bernard was remanded to the custody of the Noonan and Seward families. Almost two years later, the Donohue family successfully challenged the jurisdiction of the court to hear the earlier proceedings. The outcome of this challenge and the fate of Bernard are unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Oliver Lachapell was arrested, charged with using "obscene language in the presence of ladies," and jailed for 12 1/2 days after refusing to pay a $25 fine. Lachappel petitioned a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. He argued that cursing in front of women was not a crime, the act making it so having been repealed decades earlier. After hearing the evidence, Lachappel was released.

Berquest, petitioner, files for a Writ of Habeas Corpus which is approved by Judge Lake, and he is discharged from custody with terms. Judge Lake releases him under the condition that Berquest pays the said Karna Hansen $1,000 until their illegitimate child turns 10 years old.

Summary of Proceedings: Katie, Dora, and Lillie Sitzman were being detained by the State Board of Control at the Institution for Feeble Minded Youth for unspecified reasons. Their father, Charles Sitzman, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve them, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the children were remanded to the custody of the respondents and their father ordered to pay the court costs.

Summary of Proceedings: Frank Smith petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in an attempt to retrieve Mollie Calhoun, a fourteen-year-old girl, from the custody of W. E. Miller and his wife, which was granted. Frank maintained that Mollie's father, Joseph Calhoun, had left Mollie in his charge when he left Oregon for the Indian Territory, now Oklahoma. Although Frank admitted that he had allowed Mollie to live with the Millers in the hope that she receive an education, he asserted that instead they were "making a slave out of her." During the hearing, Frank withdrew his petition. An entry on page 34 of the Marion County Probate Index suggests that Mollie remained with the Millers.

Marines on board the American ship or vessel ""War-Hawk"" for a writ of Habeas Corpus"](hc.case.wa.0396)
Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: On December 9, 1876, nine mariners were arrested and charged with desertion after refusing to take the American Ship "War Hawk" to San Francisco. The petitioners claim they were wrongfully detained for this crime by a deputy US marshal. Instead of proceeding to the ordered location, the mariners landed at the port of discovery in Washington and were arrested there. The nine men petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, claiming neglect was the cause for not proceeding to their ordered location. Their attorneys argued that while the "War Hawk" was able to provide the plaintiffs with suitable food, it neglected to do so and was an "unseaworthy" ship. Marshall Wyckoff responded that the said marines absented themselves without permission from the master or another officer of the said "War Hawk" and before the end of said voyage contract. John R. Lewis, a King County judge, ruled that the said plaintiffs were "illegally restrained and imprisoned of their liberty" and granted their petition.

["McDonald, John W."](hc.pers.002110)|holding party|["Application of Alice Bigelow for a Writ of Habeas Corpus on Behalf of Edith and Edna Bigelow, her Daughters"](hc.case.ne.0962)
Site(s) of Significance: Home of the Good Shepherd (Omaha, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: Alice Bigelow's twin daughters Edith and Edna were placed in the Home of the Good Shepherd under two conditions: 1)They would only be there for 6 months and she could remove them whenever she wanted. 2)They would not be taught the Catholic religion. Alice's daughters were there for 1 year and 3 months and she was only allowed to see them through bars under the supervision of a woman referred to as "Mother Superior." They were also taught Catholic practices which Alice believed effected them mentally and physically. She refers to them as being "regular prisoners in fact." On March 22, 1899, Alice petitioned to get her children back and was granted custody on that same day.

Summary of Proceedings: William George Clarke, a man from Chicago, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that his two sons, Holley (19) and Caryl (8), were being deprived of their freedom by Mary E. Lyon and H. E. Wood. The respondents were the half-sibling and in-law, respectively, of Annie Carpenter Clarke, the deceased ex-wife of the petitioner and mother of the bound party who had moved to Lancaster County with the children following the divorce in 1901. Judge Holmes granted the petition. The respondents claimed that they were appointed guardians of the bound party and given control of Annie's estate by her request after her death in 1906. They also alleged that the petitioner did not ever financially support his children after the divorce. Additionally, they claimed that he had a violent temper and was addicted to "intoxicating liquors," thus not making him a suitable guardian for his children. After hearing evidence, Judge Holmes denied the writ and ordered that the children remain in custody of Lyon and Wood, but that the petitioner be able to visit them at seasonable times. In the Court's decision, they also mention that the petitioner was currently going through another divorce from his second wife. Clarke then moved for the Court to grant him a new trial, which was overruled. The appearance docket shows that the Nebraska Supreme Court affirmed the Court's decision in 1909.

Bevans petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that his ten-year-old biological daughter, Gussie Bevans, was being deprived of her liberty by Frank's ex-wife and Gussie's mother, Winnie Crandall. Frank and Winnie had divorced years previously, and the court awarded custody to F. L. Knight, whose relationship to any named party is unknown. Judge Holmes granted the petition. In her response, Crandall claimed that Frank should not be given custody because he lives in Wyoming and that Knight was not a proper guardian because he had moved with his family to York, Nebraska--away from Crandall. After reviewing the evidence, Judge Holmes ruled that custody of the bound party would be awarded to Louise R. Upton, Matron of the School for Girls (Brownell Hall) in Omaha, Nebraska for five years. Frank G. Bevans filed two additional motions, one in June of 1900 and one in June of 1901, requesting that Gussie Bevans be allowed to spend summer vacation with her parents (equally split between them), which all parties agreed to.

Summary of Proceedings: Fayette I. Foss, attorney for David Zimmerman's company, petitioned on behalf of Zimmerman claiming that the sheriff of Furnas County, Nebraska had deprived him of his liberty. Zimmerman had been arrested on a bench warrant issued by district judge D. T. Welty. Judge Hall granted the petition. After hearing evidence, he ruled that Zimmerman be released on his own recognizance after surrendering a sum of five hundred dollars, which Zimmerman did.

Summary of Proceedings: Balch was admitted to Fort Steilacoom (Hospital for the Insane) in June 1883. Admitted for "religion and incorporation and homicidal tendencies." Later in 1888 he petitions for freedom saying he is not insane. Original commitment and physician's note included. The petition was allowed but it is unknown if Balch was freed. Balch is noted for being in the Oregon First Cavalry Regiment.

Summary of Proceedings: Mary Ann Scheiber left her husband, Joseph Schieber, and took their son, Edward Schieber, with her. Joseph petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in an attempt to retrieve Edward from Mary Ann and Henry Steinberg, whom Joseph accused of being Mary Ann's lover. The petition was granted and at the hearing "proof [was] heard, and refused," suggesting that the writ was denied and Edward remained with his mother.

Summary of Proceedings: John Bellamy was arrested and jailed on suspicion of being a fugitive from slavery. Frank Burke, who knew Bellamy since he was a child and knew him to be free, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on his behalf, which was granted. At the hearing, multiple witnesses confirmed that Bellamy was free. He was ultimately released.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested on the charge of murder, George W. Davis petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that James Malone and P. H. Cooper were depriving him of his liberty. Judge Hall granted the petition, but after discovering that neither Malone nor Cooper had custody of Davis, he denied and dismissed the writ. Davis was found in the prison of the city of Lincoln. No holding party appeared, and Judge Hall ruled that Davis should remain imprisoned.

Summary of Proceedings: Louis M. Cohn petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus arguing that Sheriff McClay was depriving him of his liberty. Weeks previous, Cohn had successfully petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, was remanded to custody, and filed an appeal in the Supreme Court. While that petition was pending, Cohn successfully petitioned for a writ after he had been remanded into custody again. Judge Tibbetts ruled that because Cohn had been committed a second time for the same offense, Cohn was deprived of his liberty. Tibbetts ordered that Cohn be released.

Summary of Proceedings: After Mary Marshall and her son William Marshall entered the Home for the Friendless in 1884, William was struck ill and referred to Hattie R. Painter, a physician, and her presumed relative, Joseph Painter. In 1886, Mary Marshall petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that William Marshall was unlawfully deprived of his liberty by Hattie and Joseph Painter. After hearing testimony, Judge Pound declared that William Marshall was not deprived of his liberty. Although he ordered that William remain in the custody of the holding party, Pound ordered that the petitioner be able to visit her son at all reasonable times and that in six months she could petition to modify the custody agreement.

Hoagland in 1902. An unknown judge granted the petition, and Hoagland was served. Two years later in 1904, the court dismissed the cause for want of action by the prosecution. Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and jailed on the charge of "getting and becoming drunk and indulging in loud, boisterous and tumultuous conduct," Susie Blue and Mary Woods petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Chief of Police Hoagland was unlawfully detaining them. Judge Cornish granted the petition. After hearing evidence, he allowed the writ and ordered that Blue and Woods be released from custody. Months later, Hoagland moved for a new trial, which was denied.

Summary of Proceedings: Edward Thacker, father and guardian of Addie Thacker, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Addie Thacker was being unlawfully detained by Dora Doyle. According to secondary research, Doyle was police matron. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After reviewing evidence, Holmes appointed W. W. Towle, attorney for petitioner, as the guardian of the bound party and ordered that the petitioner pay for the care and maintenance of bound party. All parties agreed to this new custody arrangement.

Summary of Proceedings: George Schuler refused to pay a fine for "Keeping for sale malt, spirituous, and vinus liquors without a license or druggist permit." The country judge of Sarpy County, Edgar Howard, ordered his arrest for refusing to pay the fine. John W. McDonald arrested him in Douglas county. Schuler said that he was unlawfully restrained and that the mittimus was defective and that the sheriff had no authority to hold him.

Summary of Proceedings: Lafayette Robinson was being detained for unspecified reasons. Jane Williams, whose relationship to Robinson is unclear, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on his behalf, which was granted. In the meantime, Robinson posted a $200 bail and was released. The respondents failed to answer the writ, and so Robinson was released from their custody. Peter Johnstone, the police chief, was ordered to pay Williams' court costs.

Summary of Proceedings: Blanche Folson petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to challenge her detention at the "Hospital for the Insane at Hastings," now the Hastings Regional Center, which was granted. Folson claimed that her parents had assaulted her and had her committed to the asylum on false pretenses. Folson mentioned a husband and three young children. After hearing the evidence, which included commitment papers, Folson was remanded to the custody of the superintendent.

Summary of Proceedings: Milly and her two children, Eliza (6) and Bob (2), filed for a writ of habeas corpus against Mathias Rose at St. Ferdinand in the County of St Louis. Milly and her two children were unlawfully under custody of Rose and his family. The court utilized the act of the legislature of 1807 to release Milly and her children from Rose and Milly was granted the sum of $500.

Site(s) of Significance: State Reform School / State Industrial School (Kearney, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: After hearing evidence from Adrian Mills, Viola Mills' father, regarding Viola being "incorrigible" and growing up "in vice," County Judge Stewart ordered that Viola be institutionalized at the State Reform School in Kearney, Nebraska. Days later, Viola Mills petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Sheriff Samuel McClay was depriving her of her liberty. The petition was granted by Judge Addison Tibbetts. After hearing evidence, Judge Tibbetts ordered that Viola be released.

Site(s) of Significance: American Indian Boarding School at Toledo (Toledo, IA)
Summary of Proceedings: Peters was imprisoned by W.bG. Malin after it was discovered that he had secretly aided mothers of the Sac and Fox Tribe in taking their children from the American Indian Boarding School at Toledo back to the tribe's reservation. There was a previous trial in this same case which determined that Peters had been wrongfully imprisoned. The judge ruled that Malin's court appointed guardianship of the children whom Peters had taken from the school was not legal, and therefore void. The judge also ruled that the state did not have the right to interfere in the proceedings of the school, because it was a federal institution and its attendees federal wards. Furthermore, the criminal laws of the state did not apply to the Native Americans and their tribes, and would only apply if a member of the tribe was involved in an act which "brought him within the plane of the legislative jurisdiction of the state." It was argued that this would apply only in a small number of cases. The ruling of this retrial is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Ardula Porter petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to regain custody of her daughter, thirteen-year-old Clara Barnes, from her brother-in-law, J. C. Barnes, which was granted. Ardula and Joseph Barnes had gotten divorced without establishing custody of their daughter, Clara, who had been living with her father and his family when he died. According to Ardula, Joseph's brother, J. C., was refusing to allow Ardula to take custody of her daughter. The petition was dismissed during the hearing "without costs to any of the parties, the said child having ben surrendered to the petitioner."

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: The Board of Insanity for Kearney County, Nebraska had Scott Brainard committed to the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the court determined that the board had improperly sentenced Brainard, although the rest of the "proceedings in relation thereto were regular." The court remanded Brainard into the custody of the state hospital but gave the board forty-eight hours to re-sentence him, otherwise he would be discharged.

Summary of Proceedings: Frank D. Soverign claimed that he was unlawfully jailed by Constable Robert Mitchell and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus. Justice of the Peace R. W. Taylor had ordered for Soverign to be jailed on the charge of "maliciously killing a wild bird" (a hawk). After hearing evidence, Judge Pound remanded Soverign to the custody of the jailer. The appearance docket records a Supreme Court mandate on July 22, 1878, but the outcome of that mandate is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and convicted in the District Court of Sheridan County on the charge of grand larceny for stealing a cow, Herman Granger petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Warden of the Nebraska State Penitentiary Leidigh was unlawfully detaining him. He had previously appealed to the Nebraska State Supreme Court, who had upheld the verdict. Granger argued that he was imprisoned under the NE House of Representatives bill no. 87 "an act to punish cattle stealing..." when the bill had not passed, making his incarceration unconstitutional. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Holmes denied the writ and remanded Granger back into the custody of the warden.

Summary of Proceedings: Jacob Dahr was arrested and jailed in St. Louis upon an accusation of having committed highway robbery in New Orleans and fleeing from justice. He asserted that the governor of Louisiana had not submitted the proper forms to retrieve him and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Dahr was remanded to the custody of his jailer.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: Henry Leonari enlisted in the U.S. Army. He later claimed to be a minor and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. His brother, Rufus Leonari, declared that Henry was a minor and that both their parents were dead. After hearing the evidence, Henry was released. The case file includes notes on Commonwealth v. Thomas H. Cushing, Esq., an 1814 Massachusetts case holding that children without "parents, guardians or masters" could not enlist in the U.S. military.

Summary of Proceedings: Joseph Augé petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his stepson, Amadee Quevereux, from Joseph Poupenez, which was granted. Augé accused Poupenez of illegally indenturing Quevereux; Poupenez countered that he held Quevereux by virtue of an indenture of apprenticeship agreed to by Quevereux's mother. After hearing the evidence, Quevereux was released.

Summary of Proceedings: On behalf of Edward and Martha Shelmidine, William H. Moore petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that they were unlawfully detained by Gable (first name unknown), a marshal in Waverly, Nebraska. Judge Cornish granted the petition. In Gable's response, he alleges that he is holding the couple on orders of the Governor of Texas, Joseph D. Sayers, who issued an extradition warrant. In case files, Martha Shelmidine is also referred to as Mrs. M. M. Claxton. After reviewing evidence, Judge Cornish allowed the writ and ordered that the Shelmidines be released from custody. According to secondary source research, Martha was allegedly previously married in Texas and married Edward in Nebraska. She was allegedly facing charges of bigamy in Texas, which is presumably why Sayers issued an extradition warrant.

Summary of Proceedings: The Davis family petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Joseph R. Kimmel from the custody of the Kimmel family, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Joseph was remanded to the custody of the Kimmels. The Davises appealed to the state supreme court, which overturned the decision of the lower court. Ultimately, it was found that the child's father, Joseph M. Kimmel, had "voluntarily relinquished" his right to the boy. The court awarded custody of Joseph R. Kimmel to the Davis family but allowed his father to have him on Sundays as well as "four days in any month, with one week's notice."

["McDonald, John W."](hc.pers.002110)|holding party, responding party, respondent|[In the Matter of the Application of Claus Hubbard for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0930)
Summary of Proceedings: Claus Hubbard filed a writ of habeas after claiming to be unlawfully imprisoned without cause or warning. When Hubbard's lawyers went to the jail and asked what he was incarcerated for, the jailer claimed that he was arrested for vagrancy, but then changed his answer suggesting instead that he was jailed for being a “suspicious character,” which was not an offense of the law. His lawyers claimed that it was common practice for the Omaha police to throw people in jail with the goal of running them out of town. Hubbard was characterized as being a black man who had previously protested against the chief of police for throwing other black people in jail without cause and leaving them there for “indefinite lengths of time.” Therefore Hubbard believed his arrest was retaliation from the Chief. He also was in bad health and thought that if he had to stay in jail “it might even cause his death.” Ultimately, his writ was approved and he was allowed to have his case brought to the court.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: Mary Ann Speaks was born in Alexandria, Virginia--then the District of Columbia--around 1811. In 1836, Speaks claimed, her mother had her bound to Susan Blunt for ten years as an apprentice in housewifery. Blunt promised to free Speaks from her apprenticeship two years early if she agreed to accompany her to St. Louis, to which Speaks agreed. After Speaks had labored nearly eight years as an apprentice in housewifery, Blunt died without making a will. Her administrator, James Quisenberry, acknowledged that Speaks was a free woman, but desired that she pay two years' wages in order to liberate herself from the Blunt estate. When Speaks refused, Quisenberry had her jailed, and Speaks petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. Her petition invoked the law of apprenticeship, of estates, and of servitude. After hearing the evidence, Speaks was released.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings:
Patrick McDonald, a thirteen year old boy, was arrested, accused of being a vagrant, and sent to the St. Louis House of Refuge. Bail was set at $100. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, contending that minors who had parents and homes could not be vagrants, which was granted. Michael McDonald, likely his father, witnessed the petition. After hearing the evidence, Patrick was remanded to the custody of F. S. W. Gleason, superintendent of the House of Refuge. 

N.B. This case file contains two versions of the habeas corpus petition.

Summary of Proceedings: Belden Finley petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his son, Verne Finley, from the custody of Verne's grandparents, Jesse and May Carter, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was denied and Verne remanded into the custody of his grandparents. The judge ordered that Belden pay the Carters $3 per week, that the Carters teach Verne to "love and respect" Belden, that Belden be allowed to take temporary custody of Verne at "seasonable times," and that Belden be allowed to re-apply for custody of his son when he could better demonstrate his ability to care for him.

Summary of Proceedings: Andrew Rogers petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his young daughter, Lucy Rogers, from Francis Resser, which was granted. Rogers accused his wife of absconding with Lucy to Resser's home; Resser responded that Lucy and her mother were boarders and that he asserted no claim over the child. After hearing the evidence, Lucy was released into her father's custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Following the removal of the Ponca tribe from their homelands in Nebraska to poor lands in Indian Territory (Oklahoma) and the death of Standing Bear's son, Standing Bear and 29 Ponca left the Oklahoma reservation without the permission of their Indian agent. The group made their way up through Kansas and into Nebraska on foot and stopped at the Omaha Reservation. The Omaha welcomed them as they had long been allies, but orders were issued for the thirty Poncas arrest. A newspaper editor extensively published columns about the proceedings and gathered the two attorneys to make Standing Bear's case. A writ of habeas corpus was issued by Judge Elmer Dundy, and in the trial proceedings, the United States government argued that writs of habeas corpus could only be utilized by citizens of the United States or those considered "human." According to this argument, Standing Bear and Indigenous peoples at large were not considered human and therefore should not be able to use writs of habeas corpus to defend themselves in court. Standing Bear's attorneys argued that their clients had cut ties with the Ponca tribe in Oklahoma, had made their intentions known to the Indian agent, that their return to Nebraska was legal and they had not broken any laws. Judge Dundy found for Standing Bear and the group of thirty was to be released. Following the trial, Standing Bear's group was not immediately allowed to return to their homelands as the land had been given to the Lakota nor could they return to the Omaha Reservation for fear of further arrest.

Summary of Proceedings: Eleck Loan was arrested and jailed on suspicion of being a fugitive from slavery. His enslaver, Joseph Loan, maintained that Eleck had his permission to be traveling and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. On hearing the evidence, Eleck was released into the custody of Joseph.

Summary of Proceedings: Corra Cummings petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve her ten-year-old daughter, Iona Cummings, from Charles and Alice Logan, which was granted. Corra had granted custody of Iona and her unnamed eight-year-old son to the Logans on the condition that they provide the children with a proper education. Corra contended that the Logans had neglected to honor their arrangement. After hearing the evidence, Iona was released into her mother's custody. It is unclear what happened to Corra's son.

Summary of Proceedings: Charles Philbert was imprisoned for an unspecified reason. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was denied and Philbert remanded to the custody of the state penitentiary. Although he successfully motioned to file a new evidence with the court, Philbert's motion for a retrial failed.

Summary of Proceedings: Pearl Dils had taken her son, Willard Dils, to Boyd County, Nebraska while in the processing of divorcing her husband, James Dils. James petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Willard, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the court ordered that James and Pearl share custody of Willard while their divorce was pending. Each was to have custody of Willard for one week at a time, dropping the boy off at the office of James' attorney, E. E. Spencer, on Saturday afternoons. Neither was to remove Willard from Lancaster County nor take him to their relatives' homes without permission of the other. Once this was decided, James withdrew his petition.

At the hearing, Mabel and Jonathan agreed to share custody of their daughter, modifying an earlier agreement recorded on page 665 of court journal number 71. It appears that the writ was amicably dismissed.

Repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington (Seattle, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Lewis Johnson was arrested in Washington for being accused of stealing $1880 dollars from John Pritchard in a hotel in Vancouver, Canada while Pritchard was intoxicated. Witnesses Tate, Russel, and Garnett attest that Johnson had a lot of money with him around the time Pritchard's money was taken, around June 4th or 5th of 1915. While Kennedy declares cause for extradition so Johnson can be tried in Canada, Johnson petitions for writ of habeas corpus, arguing the statements against him to be untrue and without probable cause or legal evidence. Outcome is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Martin White, Omaha Police Chief, and Daniel W. Iller, sergeant on the police force, arrested Ole Jackson and at the time of the arrest Jackson had not been guilty of any offense, no complaint had been made for his arrest, and no warrant issued. The writ was granted and when the case went to court White said it was for vagrancy and suspicious character, but the judge said the charges were false and Jackson was released.

["Barber, B. S."](hc.pers.002121)|judge|[On the Matter of the Application of Walter Versteeg for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0959)
Summary of Proceedings: Walter Versteeg claims that he was deprived of his liberty by Martin J. White and H. P. Haze in the city jail in Omaha. He has been detained in the jail but there is no complaint against him whatsoever. Judge Baker affirmed an original writ of Habeas Corpus, ordering that he be discharged from being restrained of his personal liberty. The state recognized that they had received copies of the writ and that they had personally delivered the writ to H. P. Haze. The District Court Judge, W. W. Slabaugh, under the Clerk Albyn L. Frank and the Deputy A. Steere, Jr., ordered that White and Haze bring both Versteeg and documentation of their cause for his detention to court on 29 September 1898. According to the Appearance Docket, the writ was returned on 7 October 1898, signed by John W. McDonald (Sheriff).

Summary of Proceedings: O. J. Vallecott, relationship to bound party unknown, petitioned on behalf of Benjamin D. Mills claiming that an unidentified John Doe had illegally deprived Mills of his liberty. Arrested on the charge of embezzlement and sentenced to serve time in the state penitentiary, Mills had appealed his case to the NE Supreme Court, who suspended his sentence and allowed him to enter into bail. Vallecott claimed that the order from the Supreme Court supersedes any order that John Doe was acting upon. Judge Holmes granted the petition. Half a year later, the court ordered that the action be dismissed. Fate of bound party is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: C.V Storz and the other unnamed petitioner claimed they were unlawfully arrested with no legal warrant and had not committed larceny or a felony.They’re attorney demanded to know the nature of the charges and be admitted to bail. However Iller and Sigwart (Holding parties) claimed that they were not accused of any offense and therefore not to be brought in court to meet with their attorney or allowed bail. Their writ was approved, but C.V Storz and the other unnamed petitioner were not released from custody because their lawyer only filed habeas for them to obtain counsel and not to be released.

Case Name and ID: [In the Matter of the Application of Angelo Rose for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0963)
Petition or Case Title: In the Matter of the Application of Angelo Rose for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
Primary field: In the Matter of the Application of Angelo Rose for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["Thompson, Will H."](hc.pers.002108)|petitioner attorney|[In the Matter of the Application of Angelo Rose for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0963)
["Rose, Angelo"](hc.pers.002106)|petitioner|[In the Matter of the Application of Angelo Rose for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0963)
["Baker, B. S."](hc.pers.002109)|judge|[In the Matter of the Application of Angelo Rose for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0963)
["McDonald, John W."](hc.pers.002110)|holding party|[In the Matter of the Application of Angelo Rose for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0963)
Summary of Proceedings:
Angelo Rose was visiting Omaha, NE from Ohio to visit relatives. He stated that he planned to return to Ohio within 2-3 weeks and had not left Ohio for the purpose of avoiding arrest. He was arrested 28 August 1899 and had been held for two days without a hearing and had not yet been scheduled for a hearing. Further, he states that he is not guilty of any crime in any jurisdiction. It was reported that he embezzled money from individuals in Ohio but he had not yet been found guilty. The individuals who filed that report were aware that the petitioner was leaving Ohio and intended to visit Omaha, NE. 

A complaint was filed on 11 August 1899 stating that Rose left Cuyahoga County, Ohio on or around 1 August 1899 and was a fugitive of justice for embezzlement. This document was signed by George C. Cockrell, Justice of the Peace. On 31 August 1899, the writ was allowed and Judge Baker wrote to Sheriff McDonald and asked that Rose be released to the custody of the State of Ohio. On 1 September 1899, Rose was ordered to be released from the custody of Douglas County to the custody of the State of Ohio. A supplemental petition was filed on 1 September 1899 stating that the representative of the Governor of Ohio did not have authority and, further, that Rose was not a fugitive from justice per the requisition papers from the State of Ohio and that no affidavit or indictment had been produced by the Governor of Ohio stating that Mr. E. D. Barry had authority to arrest Rose. The proceedings following this second petition are detailed in case file (hc.case.ne.1449).

Summary of Proceedings: Accused of embezzlement, Thomas Van Sciever was arrested on the order of Lorenzo Crouse, governor of Nebraska. Crouse received orders for extradition from W. H. Auble, agent of the state of California on behalf of W. H. Markham, governor of California. Thomas Van Sciever, and his agent and wife Addie Van Sciever, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that chief of police P. H. Cooper and agent W. H. Auble were depriving him of his liberty. Judge Hall granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Judge Tibbetts remanded him to the custody of Sherriff Miller. Van Sciever filed a writ of error and appealed to the Nebraska Supreme Court, who in 1897 affirmed the decision.

["Hoyt, John Philo"](hc.pers.001762)|judge|[In the matter of the Application of John Heo for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.wa.0112)
Repository: Washington State Archives, Southwest Regional Branch (Olympia, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Following the death of his parents when he was about ten years old, John Heo had lived with a white family away from the Indian reservations that his parents belonged to and had severed his tribal relations for nearly twenty-five years. R. H. Milroy, the Indian Agent of the Nisqually and Puyallup Agency, arrested Heo when he refused to return to the agency and cohabit with an Indian woman, presumably his wife. Heo petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus which was granted, and the trial was heard by Judge Hoyt. Milroy argued that all Indians living in or coming to the agency are under his jurisdiction and that he was justified in requiring Heo to return to the reservation to live with his wife and child. Heo argued that because he had severed ties with his nation, had never lived on a reservation since his parents' death, and has adopted a Western lifestyle, Milroy did not have sufficient justification to arrest him. Judge Hoyt, after hearing the evidence, ruled in favor of Milroy, and Heo remained in custody.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: Institutionalized in the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane, Thomas Walton petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against superintendent James L. Greene. Judge Frost granted the petition. When Walton was judged insane by a commission, they ruled that he was not dangerous and could be released. Walton's assigned guardian, John Taylor, also claimed that Walton had the means to provide for himself if released. After hearing this evidence, Judge Frost denied the writ and ordered that Walton be remanded back into the custody of Greene.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: Jacob Penner petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that he was unlawfully detained by James L. Greene, Superintendent of the Nebraska Hospital for the Insane. Judge Cornish granted the petition. When Penner came before the court, Cornish ruled that Penner be released on his own recognizance. Cornish also set the hearing date for March 10th, 1906. The writ outcome and fate of the bound party are unknown.

["Burton, William R."](hc.pers.000249)|judge|[In the Matter of the Application of T. Judson Ferguson for writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0505)
Summary of Proceedings: T. Judson Ferguson was arrested, charged with forging a "contract or order on the Township of Alma, Harlan County, Nebraska for the sum of $50.00," and jailed. Bail was set at $350. Ferguson asserted that he was not guilty but did not post bail. He then asserted that the writ of mittimus was unlawful and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Ferguson was remanded to the custody of his jailer.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska Children's Home Society (Douglas County, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: Grace Miller, next friend and presumed relative of Herold James Miller, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Herold was being deprived of his liberty by Sadie Kingery, Elmer P. Quivey, and "the Nebraska Childrens' Home Society, a corporation." Quivery responded to the summons on behalf of the Nebraska Childrens' Home Society, a private adoption agency, and objected to the jurisdiction of the court over the Douglas County-based corporation. The court sustained the objection and dismissed the cause. The fate of the bound party is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Sam Harris was being jailed for unspecified reasons. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Harris was remanded to the custody of his jailer. Harris and his counsel made several attempts to contest this result, including motioning for a new trial, requesting bail, and preparing a bill of exceptions, but they do not appear to have succeeded in changing the judge's mind. While Harris' fate is unknown, he appears to have remained in jail.

Point(s) of Law Cited: Act of March 3, 1885; Act of Jan 15, 1897; State v. Columbia George; In Re Heff; The Dawes Act (1887)
Primary field: In the matter of the application of Columbia George for a writ of habeas corpus

["Hanford, Cornelius Holgate"](hc.pers.001516)|judge|[In the matter of the application of Columbia George for a writ of habeas corpus](hc.case.wa.0272)
["Fyre, Jesse A."](hc.pers.001603)|respondent attorney|[In the matter of the application of Columbia George for a writ of habeas corpus](hc.case.wa.0272)
Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Columbia George was convicted of murdering Anna Edna, a Cayuse woman living on the Umatilla Indian Reservation in Oregon, and was sentenced to life imprisonment. First, he was sent to the Oregon State Penitentiary at Salem, Oregon. Then, he was transferred to the custody of C. B. Hopkins at the Federal Penitentiary on McNeil's Island in Puget Sound, Washington. George appealed the decision, and George argued that because he had faced injustice by the hands of the judge. The case initially went to the Supreme Court of Oregon. The judge denied his writ of Habeas Corpus and ruled that a state court did not have the authority to rule in the case. The case was then sent to a US circuit court. George argued that the Supreme Court jurists had judged him as an Indian ward, and not a U.S. citizen who subject to both federal and state law (whereas an Indian ward would have been strictly subject to federal statute), and therefore should have granted his petition and heard the case. This was due to his receipt of an allotment of land by the U.S. government under the Dawes Act, which when accepted, changed his legal status to a U.S. citizen, an no longer an Indian Ward of the United States government. The case went to the United States District Court where the jury convicted him guilty of murder and sentenced him to life imprisonment. George appealed, and was reportedly tried again, and was once more convicted of murder. The archives lack these documents, but the case is referenced in this case, no. 1390, in Judge Hanford’s denial and dismissal of George’s petition for wrongful imprisonment by Charles E. Hopkins at the US Penitentiary at McNeil Island. George appealed a fourth time and was dismissed.

Summary of Proceedings: L. L. Lindsey petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus after County Court Judge Lansing found him in contempt of court. Lindsey appealed to the District Court claiming that Sheriff Miller was unlawfully detaining him. Judge Holmes granted the petition. In his decision, Holmes ruled that the County Court was without jurisdiction, and Holmes ordered that Lindsey be released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Ellis Harrison petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Margaret and Grace Harrison from the custody of Eileen Harrison, which was granted. At the hearing, Ellis withdrew his petition and was ordered to pay court costs. The fates of Margaret and Grace are unclear. Although nothing in the court documentation explicitly states the relationships between these parties, the 1920 census makes clear that this was a child custody case.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: John Bowler and Edward McCrink (called McCrinkle in the petition) were arrested for the charge of perjury after they testified at trial that they were beaten with brass knuckles by James H. Bennett. They filed for a habeas petition on the basis that the commissioner who arrested them did not have jurisdiction or probable cause to detain them. The petition was granted, and upon hearing the evidence, the judge granted the writ of Habeas Corpus as well. Following the writ, the judge returned to the original trial of assault and the petitioner’s attorney called multiple witnesses.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: In January of 1874, Han Lee filed a petition on behalf of Seo Kim, a Chinese woman who was allegedly being held by Ah Chow in the Seattle area. Han Lee believed that Ah Chow intended to cross the border into Victoria and sell Seo Kim. It was also known that a man named Ah Ying had obtained a marriage license to marry Seo Kim, which Han Lee believed Seo Kim desired. Han Lee previously bought Seo Kim in China and believed that he was losing his property. Ah Chow denied that he was detaining Seo Kim. When ordered by the court to bring her in, he claimed that he had never held her captive nor had he any intent on selling her across the border. Even after a court order was issued, he refused to appear before Judge Orange Jacobs. The sheriff, H.G. Thornton was ordered to arrest and bring Seo Kim into custody. He brought her in but was not able to bring Ah Chow in at that time. A warrant was then issued for Ah Chow’s arrest, but Thornton could not find him, claiming he must have been hiding out somewhere in Seattle. Seo Kim was discharged from custody and the petition was dismissed.

["Cline, Ella (Ella Dickey)"](hc.pers.001896)|responding party|["In the Matter of the Application of Elnora Cline, an Infant, by B.M. Cline, Her Father, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus"](hc.case.wa.0083)
["Cline, Elnora"](hc.pers.001897)|bound party|["In the Matter of the Application of Elnora Cline, an Infant, by B.M. Cline, Her Father, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus"](hc.case.wa.0083)
Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: On May 21, 1887, Moses Cline (also known as BM Cline or Moses Brown Cline) filed a writ of Habeas Corpus on behalf of his four-year-old daughter, Elnora Cline, in the Third Judicial District Court in King County, Washington. Elnora had been living with her mother and Moses' wife, Ella Cline, in Seattle since April 15, 1887. Moses claimed that as a single mother, Ella would be unable to maintain the best interest of Elnora and that as a caring and capable father he not only possessed a legal right to custody of his child, but that Elnora would benefit from being in his custody. In response, Ella maintained that she had a legal right to custody of Elnora and that Elnora's age required the care of her mother. While the remaining files for the case are missing following Ella's return to the writ, Elnora seems to have gone into Moses' custody for a brief period, given that Moses listed Elnora as the sole other member of his household on the 1889 Kitsap County Census.

Summary of Proceedings: Charged with highway robbery and sentenced to five years hard labor, June Bent petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against the warden of the Nebraska State Penitentiary, George Leidigh. Judge Cornish granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Cornish denied the writ and ordered that Bent be remanded back into custody. Bent was tried along with his alleged co-conspirator, William Hayes, who also petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus. See hc.case.ne.0586

Summary of Proceedings: Joseph DeKlotz was being jailed on a charge of having engaged in "gambling, chance or fraud." He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted, the judge also ordering that he be released for the duration of the proceedings. After hearing the evidence, the writ was allowed and DeKlotz released. The county attorney appealed this to the state supreme court, which affirmed the decision of the lower court.

Summary of Proceedings: Clifford B. Smith was arrested in Lancaster County on a warrant from Dakota Territory, which claimed he was guilty of grand larceny. Police Judge A. F. Parsons ordered Smith's detention with the intention of keeping him in police custody until he could be delivered to Dakota Territory authorities. Smith petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against the jailer A. C. Langdon, which was unsuccessful. The verdict was later overturned in the Nebraska Supreme Court in April 1887 by Chief Justice Samuel Maxwell.

Summary of Proceedings: Susan M. Horn was trying to regain custody of her children from the Nebraska Children's Home Society stating that they were being kept from her, mistreated, moved around, and abused. Later in the case it comes to light that she after she was widowed, she willingly gave her children up to be taken care of and had two older children who do not have the best reputation now. She had tried to regain her children before this and could never prove that she was financially stable enough to take them on and give them a better life than they had in the society homes.
