Summary of Proceedings: In 1903, Olive Anderson petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that minor children Walter and Edna Gross were being deprived of their liberty by Minnie Gross and Henry Smalley. The relationship between the petitioner and the bound party is unknown. Judge Cornish granted the petition. In 1904, the court dismissed the cause "for want of prosecution." The next month, the petitioner showed in court and Judge Holmes reinstated the case. In 1906, the court again dismissed the cause. The fate of the bound party is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: J. B. and Sarah Montgomery divorced in 1871. The Douglas County Circuit Court ordered that J. B., not Sarah, should have custody of their daughter, Mary Montgomery. Sarah refused to comply with the court order, prompting J. B. to petition for a writ of habeas corpus in Marion County, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the Marion County Circuit Court awarded custody of Mary to J. B., found Sarah to be in contempt, and ordered her to pay all court fees.

Case Name and ID: [In the Matter of Angelo Rose for Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.1449)
Petition or Case Title: In the Matter of Angelo Rose for Habeas Corpus
Primary field: In the Matter of Angelo Rose for Habeas Corpus
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["Rose, Angelo"](hc.pers.002106)|petitioner|[In the Matter of Angelo Rose for Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.1449)
["McDonald, John W."](hc.pers.002110)|holding party|[In the Matter of Angelo Rose for Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.1449)
["Thompson, Will H."](hc.pers.002108)|petitioner attorney|[In the Matter of Angelo Rose for Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.1449)
["Magney, George A."](hc.pers.002111)|petitioner attorney|[In the Matter of Angelo Rose for Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.1449)
Summary of Proceedings:
This supplemental petition was filed because Rose claimed that no “proper or legal complaint” had been filed against him as required by law. He states that he is not a fugitive from justice but was visiting relatives in Omaha and had not left Ohio for the purpose of avoiding arrest. This file offers a restatement of the facts from the prior file; Rose was arrested wrongly, he was held without trial and no news of a trial being scheduled, he claims to have not committed any crime in Ohio and, thus, cannot be a fugitive from the law.

The form from the Justice of the Peace (George C. Cockrell) states that a complaint was submitted by Deputy Sheriff Louis Grebe on 31 August 1899 stating that on or about 1 August 1899, Rose was a fugitive from justice from Common Court in Cuyahoga County, Ohio. Deputy Grebe claims that Rose stood accused of the crime of embezzlement (a sum of $300), committed in Cuyahoga County, Ohio. 

George C. Cockrell (Justice of the Peace) signed an order on 1 September 1899 to the Keeper of the Common Jail to keep Angelo Rose for “further examination,” as he had been charged with committing the offence of Fugitive from Justice. An order that the Sheriff release Rose to allow him to appear in court on 1 September 1899 was submitted on 31 August 1899 by Coblyn L. Frank (Clerk). 

Judge B. S. Baker ordered that Rose’s writ be allowed and ordered that a writ of habeas corpus be issued in favor of Angelo Rose, returnable on 1 September 1899 at 2:00pm directed to Sheriff John McDonald.

Additional People: Thompson, G. (clerk)
Case Citation(s): St. Louis Law Commissioners' Court, April Term 1856, No. 82

Summary of Proceedings: Vera Baker petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Thomas Smiley from the custody of William and Pearl Smiley, which was granted. At the hearing, counsel for the petitioner requested a recess to gather evidence in support of the "character of the home of the petitioner and its surroundings," which was also granted. At a second hearing six months later, the court denied the writ and remanded Thomas to the custody of the Smileys. Vera twice excepted to this judgement, but nothing came of her efforts.

Case Name and ID: [Matilda By the Habeas Corpus act](hc.case.mo.0019)
Encoding Notes:
I think it is correct to say for these kinds of kidnapping suits where the judge allows the bound party to be hired out as a perverse kind of bail that the habeas petition was granted but the bound party remained in custody. The bound party certainly wasn't released. 

Similar to the Anson case, there is no habeas petition here.
Petition Outcome Old: Petition granted: bound party remained in custody

Summary of Proceedings: Matilda accused Henry Mitchel and Henry Russel of kidnapping her in an attempt to reduce her to slavery. Judge Carr allowed her to sue on an action of trespass of assault and battery and false imprisonment. Carr also issued a writ of habeas corpus and stipulated that Matilda could be hired out while her case pended.

Summary of Proceedings: Calvin Lambert jailed after being charged with murder. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Lambert was denied bail and remanded to the custody of his jailer. He appealed this decision to the state supreme court, which suspended the judgement of the lower court. Lambert's fate is unknown.

["Hall, Charles L."](hc.pers.000512)|judge|["In the matter of the application of Louis Seiffer, imprisoned under the name of David S. Berman, for a writ of Habeas Corpus"](hc.case.ne.0569)
Summary of Proceedings: Louis Seiffer, alias David S. Berman, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that warden of the State Penitentiary Leidigh was depriving him of his freedom. Seiffer had been arrested on the charge of forgery, fined, and sentenced to five years imprisonment "and kept at hard labor." Seiffer claimed that before his initial trial in Furnas County's District Court, deputy sheriff A. E. Peterson insinuated that Seiffer would be lynched and hung and that the gathered crowd joined in the intimidation. Additionally, he claimed that he was told that if he pled guilty, he would only receive one year in prison. Judge Hall allowed the petition. After hearing evidence, Hall granted a Seiffer a "writ of relief" from the custody of Leidigh and ordered that Seiffer be transferred into the custody of Furnas County sheriff to await additional legal action. According to the August 11, 1895, Chicago Chronicle, Seiffer (spelled Seiffert) was a well-known forger throughout the United States.

Summary of Proceedings: Benjamin Wise was arrested on suspicion of having committed arson, arraigned before the Justice Court of Salem, and jailed to await a grand jury trial. Bail was set at $2,000. Wise paid his bail and was released only to be promptly re-arrested and jailed to answer a second charge related to the arson. Bail was set at $3,000. Wise petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. He contended that the bail was excessive. After hearing the evidence, Wise was remanded to the custody of his jailer.

Summary of Proceedings: On behalf of her next friend, Richard Seward, Kittie Noonan petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve a boy named Bernard Seward from the custody of the Donohue and Danaher families, which was granted. While the hearing was pending, Bernard was placed in the custody of Fannie Noonan. After hearing the evidence, it was determined that the petitioners retained "effectual custody" of Bernard and--since Bernard was not being detained by the respondents--the cause was dismissed without prejudice.

["Hanford, Cornelius Holgate"](hc.pers.001516)|judge|[In the matter of the application of Howard McMillen for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.wa.0445)
Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings:
Same story as Edward Crofery's in 0444. They were partners. This is 0444's summary modified:

A telegram was received by Chief of Police (Butterfield) from Vancouver's Chief of Police asking him to arrest Edward Crofery and Howard McMillan for stealing jewelry. Chief did so. Attorney filed for petition of Habeas Corpus on the grounds that there was no illegality on file by any court in the Territory. Writ is granted. The same day they realize the U. S. Marshall already came with a warrant from U.S. Commissioners Court saying they smuggled goods into the U.S.(stated in 0444). Crofery and McMillen are no longer in custody and cannot be produced to the court so writ was discharged.

Summary of Proceedings: Albert and Loretta Sheldon divorced in 1888. Five years later, Loretta, who had remarried, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to establish custody of their son, Hallie. Loretta claimed that the divorce settlement had not determined custody; Albert countered that the settlement had granted custody of Hallie and his brother, Olliver, to himself and custody of a third son, Walter, to Loretta. After hearing the evidence, Hallie was remanded to the custody of Albert and Loretta ordered to pay his court fees.

Summary of Proceedings: An unknown party petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to release Hannah and Sarah from the custody of Francis Hickman, which was granted. In his response, Hickman claimed that two strangers attacked him on the way to the courthouse and "by force took the said girls from his possession." He later accused Rolla Rose of having been the kidnapper. The fates of Hannah and Sarah are unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Molly Martin petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve her son, Earl Martin, from his grandmother, Susie Harris, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was allowed and Earl released into his mother's custody. The court, however, determined that both women were "fit and proper persons to have custody of said child," and allowed Susie to have custody of Earl one day each month and one month each summer. Molly petitioned to modify the custody arrangement a few times over the next several years, but was unsuccessful.

Summary of Proceedings: The Commissioners of Insanity of Johnson County, Nebraska had Jacob Blessing committed to the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane. Blessing claimed that he had not been permitted to testify at his commission hearing and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the court found that "no valid sentence" had been "imposed upon said applicant," allowing the writ and releasing Blessing from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested after giving his customer trading stamps which could be redeemed at his company for merchandise, James H. Flaherty petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that the ordinance used to convict him in Police Court was unconstitutional, therefore, he was being deprived of his liberty. Judge Holmes granted the petition. In his statement, Holmes claimed that the charge and arrest dealt with public morality, not public safety, thus it was not a valid exercise of police power. He also ruled that Flaherty's method of advertising was not improper, and that the ordinance he was charged with violating was unconstitutional. He cites rulings in several other states. He allowed the writ and ordered that Flaherty be released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Arthur Smith, identified as an incompetent man, was detained at the Dr. Benjamin F. Bailey Sanitarium Company, also known as the Green Gables Sanitarium. His guardian, George Smith, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. At his hearing, the respondents mounted no defense and several doctors testified to Arthur's condition. After hearing the evidence, Arthur was released.

Summary of Proceedings: Milo Yates claimed that his infant son, Frank Yates, was illegally deprived of his liberty by Frank's mother and Milo's wife, Arizona. Milo Yates petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was served to Arizona in addition to Frank and Dorcas Rader (who are the presumed parents of Arizona and grandparents of Frank). After hearing the evidence, the bound party was released back into the custody of Arizona. Milo then filed a civil suit against Frank and Dorcas Rader, which was later dismissed without prejudice to further action.

Case Name and ID: [United States vs. Mathias Rose](hc.case.mo.0029)
Encoding Notes:
No habeas petition in scan.

The habeas petition is here: http://library.uncg.edu/slavery/petitions/details.aspx?pid=17555. 

This really isn't a habeas action. It should probably be swapped out of the database for above link.
Petition or Case Title: United States vs. Mathias Rose
Primary field: United States vs. Mathias Rose
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["Rose, Mathias"](hc.pers.000303)|respondent|[United States vs. Mathias Rose](hc.case.mo.0029)
Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: An unknown party petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to challenge the detention of a woman named Milly, which was granted. Mathias Rose, accused of detaining Milly, refused to respond to the petition and was consequently held in contempt of court. For background on this incident, see Kelly M. Kennington, In the Shadow of Dred Scott: St. Louis Freedom Suits and the Legal Culture of Slavery in Antebellum America (Athens: University of Georgia Press, 2017), 88-9.

Summary of Proceedings: Frank Nelson was arrested and jailed for an unspecified reason. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. The respondent, Charles Wauzer, answered that Nelson had been removed from his custody by the sheriff of neighboring Webster County. The judge dismissed the case, acknowledging that it was now outside the court's jurisdiction. Nelson's fate is unknown.

They maintained that they were being "held without commitment" and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. They each posted a $200 bail while their hearing was pending. ["Lyon, George G."](hc.pers.001704)|authority ordering detention|[In the matter of the application of Lee Kee for a writ of habeas corpus, In the matter of the application of Lee Kee for a writ of habeas corpus](hc.case.wa.0074hc.case.wa.0075)
Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Lee Kee, is arrested on the conviction of keeping a resort for using opium, and sentenced to hard labor for 30 days, as well as a fine of $50. Wo Lin (presumably switched from Harold Preston,) attorney on behalf of Kee, petitions that he is illegally imprisoned on the basis of being charged in an alleged commitment which doesn't constitute crime, improper jurisdiction, lack of authority, and no due process of law. Lee Kee was later discharged from custody.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: According to the appearance docket, on July 5th, 1902, Milton LaMaster, a seventy-four-year-old man declared insane, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against James L. Greene, superintendent of the Nebraska Home for the Insane. Judge Holmes presumably granted the petition because the docket claims that Greene received a copy. On July 15th, Milton moved to dismiss the cause, which Judge Cornish granted. A simultaneous legal action, "In the Matter of the guardianship of Milton F. Lamaster, an insane person," exists in the records.

Summary of Proceedings: Hazel Allsman or her legal representative petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to challenge her detention by the Smith family, which was granted. While her hearing was pending, Allsman, who was a minor, was placed into the custody of Emily Hornberger, the county probation officer. Jesse Strode, the Lancaster County attorney, successfully motioned to have himself added to the case as a "party defendant on behalf of the State of Nebraska." After hearing the evidence, Allsman's writ was allowed and she was released from the custody of the Smith family.

Summary of Proceedings: William Moore was jailed for unspecified reasons. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. The court scheduled a hearing for May 24, 1921 and allowed Moore to post a $100 bail. The scheduled hearing does not appear to have happened, however, and the court dismissed the cause two years later. Moore's fate is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: John Martin served two years at the Nebraska State Penitentiary on a burglary conviction. The day he was released, he was arrested and charged with having committed an attempted robbery in Iowa several years prior. Martin claimed he had been in a different state at the time of the attempted robbery and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was allowed and Martin released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested on the charge of grand larceny, Daniel S. Conroy petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Sherriff Miller was depriving him of his freedom. Judge Holmes granted the petition; however, after hearing evidence, he remanded Conroy back into custody. One month later, Conroy filed a motion to amend the record after Sherriff Miller admitted guilt. The motion was granted, but presumably Conroy remained in custody. Two years later, a Supreme Court decision affirmed the court's decision.

Summary of Proceedings:
George Turley was arrested and jailed on suspicion of being a fugitive from slavery. He asserted that he was a free man and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, which included testimony from his parents, Turley was released.

N.B. This case file contains a letter that Turley composed to his parents in which he apologized for his penmanship, noting: "I have to write on my knee."

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings:
Coley Harris was arrested and jailed on suspicion of being a fugitive from slavery. She declared that she was a free woman and petitioned the St. Louis Criminal Court for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted by one Judge Lackland. After hearing the evidence, she was released. However, Harris, in consultation with her attorney, was then arrested and jailed for a second time in an attempt to prevent her original kidnapper, Rueben Bartlett, from seizing her again. This time she petitioned the St. Louis Commissioner's Court for a writ of habeas corpus, which was also granted. Upon hearing the evidence, Harris was once again released.

Mark Twain believed that Harris had been posing as a slave to avoid punishment for having entered the state as a free Black woman without proper license. See Mark Twain's Letters, vol. 1, 1853 to 1866, eds. Edgar Marquez Branch et al (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1988), 51. (https://books.google.com/books?id=IPgkDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA51)

Summary of Proceedings: Gaston Akoun, Madroche Zitoune, Abraham L. Reed, and S. B. Wadley worked for the Oriental Exhibition Company and were in a separate court with the Company. Akoun et al. were unlawfully detained after a violation of a pretened order of injunction in the original case against the Trans-Missisippi and International and Oriental Exhibition Company. They alleged there was no process according and that they were denied the right to be separately tried for the alleged violation of the injunction. After that trial ended, they were arrested because they hadn't paid their fines. After filing for the writ of habeas corpus, the writ was allowed, the case was heard, and it was determined they were being unlawfully held so they were released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested on the charge of gambling, James C. Morrison (alias Richard Roe) petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that he was previously granted bail and had the money, but that he was still held in custody by Sheriff Trompen. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After reviewing the evidence, he allowed the writ and released Morrison on bail.

Summary of Proceedings: Frances Fidler petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to establish who should have custody of her daughter, Mary Thomas, then living with her grandmother, which was granted. By the mutual consent of both parties, they recessed for thirty days. At the hearing, Frances, alongside Mary's father, Archie Thomas, asked that custody of Mary be given to the child's grandmother, also named Mary Thomas. The judge agreed to this new arrangement, and Mary was remanded to the custody of her grandmother and namesake.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Frank Krebs and Pat Daughtery were detained by John McGraw and charged by J. F. Miller of crime of Assault. They filed Habeas because the justice of the peace exceeded his jurisdiction by trying to commit them to the custody of the sheriff and fine them $10 each immediately. The writ was granted but upon hearing the evidence, judge C. H. Hanford ordered that Frank and Pat would spend 16 days in jail.

Summary of Proceedings: In July of 1887, Louis Leiberman, a Jewish naturalized U.S. citizen, was arrested on the charge of violating the city of Lincoln's Sunday ordinance. He argued in his habeas corpus petition that police judge Albert F. Parsons violated his right to due process and that his business, a general goods store, exempted him from following the ordinance; therefore, he was being deprived of his liberty by Marshall P. H. Cooper. In April of 1888, Judge Allen Field remanded Leiberman into custody until he was released on bond on April 24th on the sum of $100.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: Napoleon Johnson was arrested and jailed. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted, asserting that he did not know any reason why he should be detained. His jailer responded that Johnson was being detained because a ship captain had accused him of "stealing a watch & pistol," but that the only witness, an unidentified Black man, could not testify because he was away on a boat. After hearing the evidence, Johnson was released.

Summary of Proceedings: Charged with highway robbery and sentenced to five years hard labor, William Hayes petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against the warden of the Nebraska State Penitentiary, George Leidigh. Judge Cornish granted the petition. After reviewing the evidence, Cornish denied the writ and remanded Hayes back into the custody of Leidigh. Hayes was originally tried with his alleged co-conspirator, June Bent, who also petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus. See hc.case.ne.0585

Summary of Proceedings: Joe Lachapell was arrested, charged with using "obscene language in the presence of ladies," and jailed for 12 1/2 days after refusing to pay a $25 fine. Lachappel petitioned a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. He argued that cursing in front of women was not a crime, the act making it so having been repealed decades earlier. After hearing the evidence, Lachappel was released.

Summary of Proceedings: Lucia Martinez filed for a writ of habeas corpus on behalf of her two daughter, Clara A and Johana Martinez who were being held by one of the defendants, Thomas Barman. The hearing was postponed to August 30 1871 so the defendants had time to collect their evidence and witnesses. Before the hearing took place, Martinez approached the judge and requested the dismissal of the case, and both parties agreed to drop the case. By order of Judge Alsop Clara and Johana were to stay in the custody of the sheriff until the August hearing had ended.

Case Name and ID: [In re Application of John F. Decker, for a writ of habeas corpus](hc.case.ne.0598)

Summary of Proceedings: John F. Decker petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that he was unlawfully detained by Sheriff Nicholas Ress. Judge Holmes granted the petition and allowed him bail at the sum of 300 dollars. Decker had been arrested on the charge of perjury after he falsely claimed during a divorce trial that he was a resident of Lancaster County, Nebraska. After hearing evidence, Judge Holmes ruled that Decker had not committed perjury and therefore was being illegally detained. He ordered that Decker be released from custody. However, he ordered that the County Attorney, James L. Caldwell, prosecute Decker for the charge of contempt of court and punish him accordingly. Caldwell immediately followed through in State of Nebraska vs John F. Decker where again Decker was released on bail. The outcome of this case is unknown. Weeks later, Caldwell produced a motion for a re-hearing and a new trial for Decker's habeas corpus case, which the court overruled. In 1906, Caldwell's appeal was tried in the Nebraska Supreme Court, who later dismissed his petition in error.

Summary of Proceedings: Ray Rickard petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his daughter, Dorothy Rickard, from the custody of Catherine Kleeman and Martha Peer, which was granted. Martha responded that although her mother, Catherine, had Dorothy, who was her granddaughter, in her possession, neither woman claimed custody of the girl. After hearing the evidence, the judge ordered that Catherine either deliver Dorothy to her father or demonstrate in court why she should not have to do so. A few months later, Ray withdrew his petition, suggesting he had secured custody of Dorothy.

Holmes also ruled that Frazier be allowed to bail provided he pay the sum of 500 dollars. It is unknown whether Frazier posted bail.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: In August of 1882, Alice McKay placed her daughter, Mary, into the care of the Sisters of Charity for Mary to receive care as she recovered from Scarlet Fever. A month later, the Sisters placed Mary into the care of John and Della Keevan, telling Alice that they were doing so for Mary to receive "fresh country air." Alice argued that she had frequently attempted to visit Mary and retrieve her from the Keevans, but was prevented from doing so after the Keevans threatened to shoot her. Alice claimed that the Keevans "unlwafully and cruelly bed, abuse, and otherwise ill treat" Mary, and that the Keevans had no legitimate legal claim to the custody of Mary. The Keevans responded by claiming that Alice abandoned Mary and left her in a poor physical condition, and that "by reason of this poverty and indigent circumstances she was unable to support and maintain it." The Keevans further argued that they were financially and mentally capable of providing Mary with a moral education and superior material means. While the case file itself does not contain a case outcome, it is indicated in Alice's second petition for custody of Mary in 1887 that this writ was denied on account of Alice's poverty.

Summary of Proceedings: Robert Welts was convicted of selling liquor without a license in Kearney County, Nebraska and fined $100. Since Welts could not pay, he was jailed. After serving for some time, he was released, only to be jailed again in Adams County. Welts declared that he was insolvent and had served long enough to satisfy his debt under state law. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Welts was released.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: After being institutionalized in Lincoln's Hospital for the Insane, William Golden initially petitioned for the appointment of a commission to determine his sanity. His petition was denied because he had not been admitted six months prior to the application. A week later, Golden petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Supt. H. W. Mathewson had illegally deprived him of his liberty. Dr. Hay, S. J. Tuttle, A. C. RIcketts, and T. J. Fuller were subpoenaed. After hearing evidence, Judge Pound ordered that he be returned to Mathewson's custody.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Chad F. Reed was arrested for obtaining money under false pretenses and filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus because there was no paper writing showing he had been convicted of any offense. Upon hearing the evidence, the judge ruled that the return to the writ previously filed by the justice of the peace was invalid and therefore C. F. Reed should be released on bail.

Repository: Reports of Cases Argued and Determined in the Supreme Court of the State and Territory of Kansas
Summary of Proceedings: On October 16, 1868, an order had been issued by Charles E. Mix, the U.S. Commissioner of Indian Affairs, that stated that Native peoples would not be allowed to visit Washington D.C. due to lack of federal funding. Moses Keokuk, the Chief of the Sac & Fox Indians, used his own money to leave the reservation and visit Washington. On his way out of Kansas, he was arrested on November 23, 1868 by Albert Wiley, the Indian Agent for the Sac & Fox Indians.  On this order, Keokuk was transported to the county jail of Douglas County and held there for two days. Keokuk petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus which was granted. He continue to sue for damages against Wiley. After hearing the evidence, the jury found for Keokuk. Wiley filed for a new trial, and appealed to the Kansas Supreme Court. After reviewing the evidence, the Supreme Court of Kansas upheld the decision of the District Court.

Summary of Proceedings: Minnite Tarlton, by way of Fred L. Smith, alleged that she was arrested for no reason. When the court responded, they said that there existed no person by the name of Tarlton, but instead there was a Mabel Whitecomb. Whitecomb was arrested for prostitution, vagrancy, and suspicious character by Martin White and Daniel W. Iler. Smith filed for a writ of habeas corpus by which Tarlton, alias Whitecomb, was released from prison.

Summary of Proceedings: Flora Ohler and Joseph Gielday divorced in January 1893. Custody of their two young daughters, Naomi and Leona Gielday, was awarded to Flora. According to Flora, she moved to Iowa and re-married, while Joseph moved to Red Willow County, Nebraska, and took ill. Flora allowed Naomi and Leona to visit Joseph in order to help take care of him. At some point, Leona returned to her mother while Naomi remained with her father. When Joseph died in February 1898, a pair of brothers named Charles and George Shafer contrived to have custody of Naomi awarded to Charles, arguing that she had no relatives living in the state. Flora petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Naomi, which was granted. Flora argued that she was Naomi's rightful guardian and that Charles "only desires the custody of said minor child to gratify his own licentious designs and to accommodate the lust of his single brother George." Charles countered that Flora was an abusive mother, that Naomi remained with the Shafers of her own volition, and that the District Court of Lancaster County, Nebraska had no jurisdiction over Red Willow County. After hearing the evidence, fourteen-year-old Naomi Gielday was remanded to the custody of Charles Shafer.

["Dickinson, Charles T."](hc.pers.002174)|judge|[On the Matter of the Application of Samuel Douglas for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0955)
Summary of Proceedings:
Petitioner claims that he is unlawfully deprived of his liberty by Chief Gallagher in Omaha. He states that he does not know the cause of his detention and that no complaint has been filed against him anywhere in the state of Nebraska which would charge him with “the commission of any crime or being a fugitive from justice.” The petitioner was informed that Gallagher arrested him at the request of an officer from Oklahoma based on a request being sent by telegram. The petitioner has not seen the telegrams and has no means of procuring a copy. Therefore, he asked that a writ of habeas corpus be issued so he can be discharged from the unlawful imprisonment. 
Judge Simpson (?) allowed the writ on 23 March 1898. On 25 March 1898 Judge Slabaugh dismissed the cause and sustained the motion of the writ, ordering that Douglas be released.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Henry Carlton was arrested by N. Soderberg, the Justice of the Peace for Seattle, in April 1888 and was convicted of the crime of vagrancy by gambling. Carlton petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, arguing that the commitment from N. Soderberg did not show Carlton had been convicted, that the court who issued the commitment did not have jurisdiction over the issue, and that it was not a commitment at all. R. A. Jones, a District Judge, ordered that the defendant should remain in custody on April 28, 1888, and Carlton returned to the custody of William Cochrane, the sheriff of King County, Washington Territory.

Summary of Proceedings: J. H. Wilcox, next friend of bound party Lizzie Hendrickson, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that sheriff deputy A. M. Trimble wrongfully placed Hendrickson in the Home for the Friendless. This case follows a county court habeas petition for Hendrickson's freedom, which was filed by her foster father, Nels Danielson. Judge Tibbetts granted Wilcox's petition. After hearing evidence, he judged that Lizzie be released from Trimble's custody.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: A telegram was received by Chief of Police (Butterfield) from Vancouver, Canada's Chief of Police asking him to arrest Edward Crofery (and a Howard McMillan) for stealing jewelry. Chief did so. Attorney filed for petition of Habeas Corpus on the grounds that there was no illegality on file by any court in the Territory. Writ is granted. The same day they realize the U. S. Marshall already came with a warrant from U.S. Commissioners Court saying they smuggled goods into the U.S.. Crofery is no longer in custody and cannot be produced to the court so writ was discharged.

Summary of Proceedings: Hermann Reiter alleged that his wife, Johanna Reiter, had left him and taken their four children. He said that Johanna could not care for them, and was a woman of "vicious and vulgar habits". He asked the children be returned to his custody. When Johanna presented her case the judge could see no issue with the state or cleanliness of the children and reported they chose to stay with their mother initially. The outcome of the case was that Hermann regained custody of the four children after the final day of trial.

Case Name and ID: [In re-Application of George Compton for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0939)
Petition or Case Title: In re-Application of George Compton for Writ of Habeas Corpus
Primary field: In re-Application of George Compton for Writ of Habeas Corpus
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["Slabaugh, W. W."](hc.pers.002120)|judge|[In re-Application of George Compton for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0939)
["Compton, George"](hc.pers.002214)|petitioner, bound party|[In re-Application of George Compton for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0939)
["McDonald, John W."](hc.pers.002110)|holding party|[In re-Application of George Compton for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0939)
["Gordon, S. J."](hc.pers.002153)|authority ordering detention|[In re-Application of George Compton for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0939)
["Lapsley, D. L."](hc.pers.002216)|petitioner attorney|[In re-Application of George Compton for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0939)
Summary of Proceedings:
Petitioner, George Compton, was arrested on 21 April 1898 on a vagrancy charge. On that same day, he was assigned to the county jail for a period of 30 days. He was not granted a trial at this point. 
Police Judge Gordon issued a mittimus, stating that this 30 day sentence had been imposed at an earlier date but was suspended based on the condition that Compton leave the city and not return. The initial sentence had been imposed on 6 December 1897. The Police Judge asserts that he failed to comply with these terms; leading to his arrest in Omaha on the charge of vagrancy, and was placed in the County Jail to complete his initial sentence. On 21 April 1898, a writ for the offense of vagrancy was submitted by Police Judge Gordon and signed by Sheriff McDonald and Deputy Sheriff Lewis detailing these claims. 
The case was heard by the District Court (Judge Slabaugh) on 6 May 1898. During this trial, Judge Slabaugh determined that no offense had been committed, that Compton was unlawfully being deprived of his liberty, and that Sheriff McDonald should release him from custody. On 7 May 1898, Judge Slabaugh signed an Order to Discharge the Prisoner on Writ of Habeas Corpus. 
On 17 May 1898, a document was submitted by the Albyn L. Frank (District Court Clerk) motioning for Douglas County to pay the costs of the trial.

Case Name and ID: [In the matter of the application for writ of Habeas Corpus of H. W. Hull](hc.case.wa.0409)
Court Name(s): Third Judicial District Court for the Territory of Washington
Petition Type: carceral: keeping a house of ill repute
Petition or Case Title: In the matter of the application for writ of Habeas Corpus of H. W. Hull
Primary field: In the matter of the application for writ of Habeas Corpus of H. W. Hull
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["Hull, H. W. "](hc.pers.001700)|petitioner|[In the matter of the application for writ of Habeas Corpus of H. W. Hull](hc.case.wa.0409)
["Greene, Roger Sherman"](hc.pers.001567)|judge|[In the matter of the application for writ of Habeas Corpus of H. W. Hull](hc.case.wa.0409)
Repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington (Seattle, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: H.W. Hull was previously tried and convicted for "keeping a house of ill repute." The judge set a fine of $300 or a unspecified amount of jail time at he King County Jail. When he did not pay the fine, Hull was placed in the custody of the King County Sherriff at the King County Jail. Hull filed a writ of habeas corpus arguing that he should be entitled to bail and was being illegally kept without a set bail. Judge Greene granted the writ and set a bail amount of $500 to go into effect on July 1, 1884, the first day of the Supreme Court of Washington Territory's new session. In Olympia, WA, he could be let out of jail before the territorial Supreme Court with a payment of $500. Hull's fate following the April 25, 1884 ruling is unknown.

Repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington (Seattle, WA)
Site(s) of Significance: King County Juvenile Detention Home (Seattle, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Gladys Fuson, a married seventeen-year-old, was arrested in Port Townsend, the seat of Jefferson County, Washington, charged with delinquency after deserting her husband, and transported to the King County Juvenile Detention Home in Seattle. She petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus by her next friend, Lona McMasters, which was granted. Gladys, whose husband, Harold Fuson, was seeking a divorce, declared that Harold had orchestrated her detention as retribution for her leaving his household and in order to prevent her from defending herself in the divorce suit. The respondents countered, citing jurisdictional and procedural reasons why the writ of habeas corpus should not lie. After hearing the evidence, Gladys was remanded back into the custody of the superintendent of the King County Juvenile Detention Home.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: On January 4th, 1886, G. W. Caufield committed Charles Barnes to the jail of King County, Washington Territory for 35 days or until Barnes paid a total of $104.55 in fines for his involvement in the breaking and entering of the house of Charles Forger and the shooting of Eugene Cote by John Barnes on January 3, 1886 in a dispute over a child. On January 6, 1886, Barnes and his lawyers filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus to Judge Roger S. Greene in King County claiming that Barnes had not received due process under the law and was being held without a trial or the court filing any charges against him. Greene granted the petition and the writ of Habeas Corpus was filed, however, the case files following the writ are missing. A newspaper article covering the case on January 7, 1886, states that Barnes was released from custody on the evening of the 6th and would be required to come before a jury regarding his January 4th charges. The fate of Charles following his release is unknown.

Durham petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on behalf of Sylvia May Durham (his presumed daughter) claiming that Frank and Corey Drury (presumed maternal grandparents of Sylvia) illegally deprived Sylvia of her freedom. The holding party produced the body of Sylvia, but there is no record of testimony. Months later, the petitioner moved to dismiss the case, which the unnamed judge granted. The fate of the bound party is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Chin Quock Wah petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in 1915. Hoping to have joined his father in Boston, MA, Chin Quock Wah was detained in Seattle, WA and was denied admittance into the U.S. His petition was granted, however the writ was dismissed by Judge Neterer. Chin Quock Wah appealed to the Supreme Court, to which the following proceedings and Chin Quock Wah's fate remains unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and jailed for selling liquor without a valid license, Mark J. Wilbur petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that his license was valid, therefore, he was being unlawfully detained by sheriff Ress. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After reviewing evidence, he denied the petition and ordered that Wilbur be remanded back into custody. Wilbur moved the Court for a rehearing, which was overruled. Wilbur then appealed to the NE Supreme Court, who ruled in favor of Wilbur and ordered that he be released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and jailed on the charge of "by means of certain bogus checks and worthless checks... to confidence a certain man," Charles Burtt-alias Charles DeFrance-petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against Chief of Police Hoagland. Judge Cornish granted the petition. In his answer, Hoagland claims that Burtt is "well known to the police officers of the City and other cities of the West, as a professional confidence man." After reviewing the evidence, Judge Cornish allowed the writ and ordered that Burtt be released from custody.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: In a former case, William Wiggins was charged with grand larceny for taking money from the Occidental Hotel safe through a complaint brought by the petitioner, William Fox. After Wiggins was found not guilty in his case, William Fox was charged with the court costs. Fox was unable to pay and detained and sentenced to forty-one (41) days of hard labor for refusal to pay a fine. Afterward, Fox filed for a writ of habeas corpus, arguing his complaint against Wiggins was not frivolous, and, therefore he should not be charged with the court costs. Judge J. R. Lewis grants the writ, and Fox is released.

Summary of Proceedings: Percival Tully petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his thirteen-year-old daughter, Alice Tully, from George Fisher, which was granted. Percival accused George of illegally detaining Alice; George responded that Percival had given him custody, which Percival denied. After hearing the evidence, Alice was released into the custody of her father.

Summary of Proceedings: J.H McConnell filed a habeas corpus petition and application on December 12th 1898. McConnell claimed that her was unlawfully restrained by John McDonald (Sheriff of Douglas County) and George Shand (jailer of Douglas County). He was arrested and charged with providing a false and forged railroad ticket from the Union Pacific Railroad Company knowingly, with the intent to commit fraud. The judge ruled that there wasn't sufficient enough evidence for his arrest and McConnell was released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: In 1886 Can- ah- couqua filed for a writ of habeas corpus to regain custody of her son who had been at the Indian Training School at Sitka, AK for three years without leave. The defendants argued that Can-ah-couqua had signed an agreement with the school in 1883-when her son was five years old- to relinquish her parental custody for a period of five years. They argued that it was for the well being and education of the boy, Con-ca-bach, that he remain in the school and not be allowed to return to his "uncivilized" mother. Can-ah-couqua argued that she had never been presented any sort of contract or verbally agreed to give- up custody of her son to the school. She further asserted that Con-ca-dach was suffering physically from the poor conditions of the school building, overworked, and unfed. He was also frequent physically and verbally abused by teachers and other staff members of the school. Furthermore, she had not been able to see her son in three years, since he had been taken from her. As part of the petitioner's evidence, Can-ah-couqua;'s attorney submitted a letter that had been written by Con-ca-dach to the governor of Alaska, A. P. Swineford, saying that he wished to be taken out of the school, and returned to his mother. Judge Dawson ruled in favor of the defendants, writing that Can-ah-couqua had relinquished custody for five years in her "agreement" with the school, and it was in the best interest of the child to continue to receive a proper education. Can-ah-couqua was, however, allowed to occasionally visit Con-ca-dach at the school, provided that the there was adequate supervisor by school officials.

Summary of Proceedings: Grace LaVonne petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve her daughter, Virginia LaVonne, from the custody of Sarah Gregory, which was granted. In their response to the writ, Sarah's counsel requested further time to prepare their defense, which was allowed, during which time the judge determined that Grace should have temporary custody of Virginia. At the hearing, Sarah's counsel mounted no defense, and Virginia was remanded to the custody of her mother.

Case Name and ID: [Michael, a boy of color vs. Henry G. Mitchel and Henry C. Russel](hc.case.mo.0020)
Encoding Notes:
I think it is correct to say for these kinds of kidnapping suits where the judge allows the bound party to be hired out as a perverse kind of bail that the habeas petition was granted but the bound party remained in custody. The bound party certainly wasn't released.

How come when I added Matilda and Anson as Relationships, they did not populate the People column for this case? Hmmm... 

Like with the Anson and Matilda cases, there is no habeas petition.

Repository: National Archives at Kansas City (Kansas City, MO)
Site(s) of Significance: American Indian Boarding School at Toledo (Toledo, IA)
Summary of Proceedings: Lelah Puc-Ka-Chee was detained by Indian Agent, W. G. Malin and brought to a the American Indian Boarding School at Toledo, Iowa. She was brought there under the guardianship of her court-appointed guardian, Malin. Her husband petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus under his and her name. Circuit judge, O. P. Shiras ruled that Malin had no right to guardianship over Lelah Puc-Ka-Chee, who was released from his custody and was granted her freedom. Furthermore, Shiras asserted that as a married woman, and therefore a legal adult, Puc-Ka-Chee had the right to decide whether or not she would remain enrolled at the school.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Fannie Fowle's lawyer (Lewis, James H.) states in the petition that she is unlawfully restrained against her will by George J. Finleyson (a British citizen). The petitioner believes there is no other cause of her restraint "other than unkindness and willful desire to make a slave" of her. They also site in the petition that George calls her his slave and that she could not leave. Fannie "frequent made attempts to get away" which resulted in the respondent catching her and "severely beat and wound her" for attempting to leave. It is stated she is being held "in the County of King on a Street of said City known as Third Street between what is known as Columbia and Madison Street, just one door from the said Columbia street next to the certain hotel known as the Columbia House." The petition was granted and the writ was served on Finleyson, but there is no further information about her release.

Summary of Proceedings: On July 16, 1886, notary public William J. Houston was tasked with receiving a deposition from Bertha Dogge on a civil case, Hart Bros., et al vs. Otto Dogge, Bertha Dogge, and Christian G. Herald. Bertha Dogge refused, and Houston found her in contempt of court and ordered her arrest. On July 22, 1886, Bertha Dogge petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that sheriff Samuel Melick had unlawfully deprived her of her freedom. After examining the evidence, Judge Pound remanded her into the custody of Melick. The next day, Supreme Court Judge Amasa Cobb upheld the decision, but he allowed Bertha to file a writ of error and ruled that Bertha be able to be released on her own recognizance provided that she pay a sum of $250.

Site(s) of Significance: Friends Mission School for Indians on Douglas Island (Douglas Island, AK)
Summary of Proceedings: A Native mother, Ah- lit- quah, allegedly signed an agreement with the Friends Mission School for Indians on Douglas Island that placed her 3 year old daughter, Nu- Shukk (Sarah Woodard) in the school. According to the document signed by a representative from the school and Ah- lit- quah, Nu-Shukk was also placed in the custody of Charles N. Replogle until she reach 18 years of age, or was discharged by Replogle for whatever reason. Ah- Lit- Quah took her daughter out of school shortly after enrollment and refused to return the child to the superintendent. Replogle filed a writ of habeas corpus for the child. The writ was granted and Judge Warren Truitt ordered Ah- lit- quah to bring Nu- Shukk to court. When she did not comply with the order, a warrant for her arrest was issued. Ah- lit- quah was arrested and Nu- Shukk was returned to the boarding school under the custody of Replogle.

Summary of Proceedings: William P. Keif was arrested for allegedly selling liquor without a license, and was jailed on the order of Police Judge William J. Houston. Keif petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus. He claimed that Marshall Phillip H. Cooper was illegally detaining him and that his right to due process was violated. Judge Samuel M. Chapman remanded him into custody but ruled that Keif could enter into his own recognizance for a sum of $200.

Summary of Proceedings: Lulu Dawson petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to establish custody of her daughter, Lucile Dawson, which was granted. At the hearing, the respondents, William and Myrtle Headrick, asserted that they made "no claim" to Lucile. Lulu therefore withdrew her petition on the advice of her attorney and paid the court costs.

Summary of Proceedings:
Hiram Smith enlisted in the U.S. Army. His father, Daniel Smith, declared that he was a minor and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve him, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Hiram was released.

(This case folder also contains case No. 107 from February Term 1855)

Summary of Proceedings: A. B. Burks was being jailed for unspecified reasons. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was allowed and Burks released from custody. Since Burks had submitted his petition to the state district court, however, he had been detained on federal charges. The state district court found that the federal court should have "awaited the determination of this action" before commencing its proceedings, confirming that Burks should be released.

Case Name and ID: [In the Matter of the Application of Janet McKay, formerly Janet Roy, for a writ of habeas corpus](hc.case.wa.0204)
Court Name(s): US District Court for the Western District of Washington
Petition Outcome Old: Petition granted: bound party remained in custody
Petition or Case Title: In the Matter of the Application of Janet McKay, formerly Janet Roy, for a writ of habeas corpus
Primary field: In the Matter of the Application of Janet McKay, formerly Janet Roy, for a writ of habeas corpus
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["Mackay, Janet ", "Mackay, Valentine (Ian Valentine Mackay)"](hc.pers.001801hc.pers.002021)|petitioner|["In the Matter of the Application of Janet McKay, formerly Janet Roy, for a writ of habeas corpus"](hc.case.wa.0204)
["White, Henry M."](hc.pers.001866)|respondent|["In the Matter of the Application of Janet McKay, formerly Janet Roy, for a writ of habeas corpus"](hc.case.wa.0204)
Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Janet Mackay, formerly Janet Roy, a Scottish woman residing in the US was arrested on June 24th, 1918 for plotting to overthrow the US government and holding materials advocating sedition and socialism. She and her sister initially immigrated to New York in October of 1916, where they worked as housekeepers. They then head to Chicago where they find work in bindery for the newly formed Industrial Workers of the World.​​ In October 1918 the Roy sisters moved to Seattle, Washington despite investigation into their ties to the IWW. The are arrested shortly after. The sisters are held in custody by Henry M. White, the sheriff and US Commissioner of immigration for Seattle. The case is heard by judge Jeremiah Neterer in the US District Court for Washington. While temporarily out on bond and while awaiting deportation, Janet marries Ian Valentine Mackay, a fellow Scottish immigrant who believes he is a naturalized citizen. The court dismissed his claim of citizenship and the marriage did not certify Janet a citizen who cannot be deported. Mackay's attorney repeatedly asks about the fairness of the case-in part because of the relationship between Judge Neterer and defendant White. In March of 1919 the case is decided and Janet’s application for a Writ of habeas is denied. Janet Mackay is officially ordered to be deported.

Case Name and ID: [On the Application of Henry Bell for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0946)
Petition or Case Title: On the Application of Henry Bell for Writ of Habeas Corpus
Primary field: On the Application of Henry Bell for Writ of Habeas Corpus
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["McDonald, John W."](hc.pers.002110)|holding party|[On the Application of Henry Bell for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0946)
["Slabaugh, W. W."](hc.pers.002120)|judge|[On the Application of Henry Bell for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0946)
["Bell, Henry"](hc.pers.002178)|petitioner|[On the Application of Henry Bell for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0946)
["Smith, Fred L. "](hc.pers.002179)|petitioner attorney|[On the Application of Henry Bell for Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0946)
Summary of Proceedings:
Bell has been held by Sheriff McDonald for over a week, the cause of his detention is unknown to him. Petitioner Henry Bell is, thus, asking for a writ of habeas corpus to be issued on the grounds of unlawful imprisonment (deprivation of liberty). The writ was filed and granted on 2 April 1898. Judge Slabaugh ordered that Bell be returned on 4 April 1898, directing that order to Sheriff McDonald. A copy of the writ was officially filed with the Sheriff on 2 April 1898. A document was entered to the record stating that Henry Bell should be kept in custody for further examination as he had been charged with drunkenness on 26 March 1898; this record was signed and ordered by Police Judge Samuel I. Gordon. 

Bell appeared in court on 4 April 1898 and Judge Slambaugh signed an order releasing him on that same day stating, “it is therefore ordered that said Henry Bell be discharged from the custody of John McDonald Sheriff and from said unlawful detention."

On 17 May 1898, a motion was filed by Ablyn L. Frank (Clerk for the District Court) asking that the costs be taxed to Douglas County and paid out of the County Treasury. The motion was sustained and the County was ordered to pay the sum.

Additional People: Bass, D.W. (notary public); Hopkins, R.M. (clerk); Hannon, H.T. (deputy clerk)

Summary of Proceedings: Samuel Jackson, a Chilkat Alaskan Native, was arrested after he "struck one M. A. Reason with his hands and fists" at the Chemawa Indian School. He was charged with assault and battery in the Justice's Court of Salem, Oregon and jailed when he refused to pay the $20 fine. Jackson petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in the Marion County Circuit Court, which was granted. Jackson argued that the Justice's Court did not have the jurisdiction to try him, since he committed the offense on federal land. After hearing the evidence, Jackson was released. ; A second petition was found in this file. There is no obvious relationship between the two petitions.

Summary of Proceedings: John Barton petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his nephew and ward, Horatio Marsden, from Stephen Denny, who was Marsden's brother-in-law. (The documentation vacillates on whether Barton or Marsden was the legal petitioner.) Barton accused Denny of illegally detaining Marsden. Denny countered that he did not detain Marsden, but rather that Marsden chose to live with him; that Barton was abusive; and that, in any case, Marsden had departed from his home. The court granted Barton's petition, but Marsden's fate is unknown.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: Aspasia was born in Kaskaskia, Illinois around 1806 to an enslaved mother who allegedly had been brought to the region before the passing of the Northwest Ordinance of 1787. Aspasia was treated as enslaved herself and sold to multiple parties. In 1821, Pierre Menard purchased the girl from Baptiste Gindreau. Shortly thereafter, Menard gave Aspasia to his daughter and son-in-law, Bernice and Francois Chouteau, who brought her to St. Louis. Late in 1827, Aspasia petitioned for the right to sue as a poor person and to have her freedom determined by the court. She charged Francois Chouteau and Pierre Menard with assault, battery, and false imprisonment and asked for $1,000 in damages. In response to the charge, Menard had Aspasia jailed, at which point she petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. Her fate is unknown, although the defendants in her freedom suit claimed that she was legally enslaved because her mother had been brought to Northwest Territory before the passage of the 1787 Ordinance, which broadly prohibited the introduction of enslaved people into the region.

He was fined $100 dollars for selling alcohol without a permitted license and was told he would be imprisoned until that fine was paid. Bancroft refused to pay so he was placed in jail. The writ was approved and he was asked to come before the court to plead his case.

Summary of Proceedings: Taik (Emma Hamilton) was a 13 year old Tlingit girl who was taken to the Sheldon Jackson Institute (aka Indian Training School at Sitka) in January of 1885 by Sheldon Jackson and Alonzo E. Austin. Taik's mother was said to have died around March 1885, and one Anna Vine became the parent- appointed guardian of the child. The story was that after the death of Hitch- sah- See, Taik's mother, Vine came in March 1885 to take Taik from the school to her home in Victoria, British Columbia, the school administrators, including Jackson and Austin refused to grant the release. When her complaints for release went unanswered, Hitch- sah- See filed for a writ of habeas corpus with her husband, Don- ah- Clah, against Jackson, Austin, and a woman referred to as "Mrs. McFarland." After the case was filed it was discovered that Taik's mother had not actually died, but was still alive, as was her father, Don-ah-clah. The case was transferred to them, and they became the new petitioners. The defendants argued that they had made a verbal agreement to enroll Taik for a period of 5 years in the school with her parents. With this alleged verbal agreement, the defendants claimed to be the legal guardians of Taik.  Judge Ward McAllister ruled against the defendant, in favor of Hitch- sah- see and Don-ah-clah. He wrote that the school officials had no authority to make "contracts with Indians" under the provisions of the federal government. Additionally, administrators could not take Native children from their parents, and were required to return them if that's what parents wished.

Summary of Proceedings: Oliver Filley, the mayor of St. Louis, accused Eliza Edwards of exposing her nine-year-old daughter, Martha, to a house of prostitution she was running, for which offense Martha was arrested and removed from her mother's custody. Eliza petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve her daughter, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the court ruled that Eliza could regain temporary custody of Martha on the condition that she leave St. Louis "to return with it to it's [sic] father."

Summary of Proceedings: J. J. Blevins petitioned for writs of habeas corpus in the county and circuit courts to retrieve his three young sons, Henry, John, and Thomas, from his father-in-law, Thomas Small, both of which were granted. Smalls claimed that his grandchildren refused to return to their father, saying that they "cried Piteously" at the thought of leaving. Smalls added that Blevins was an unfit parent, and that for the past three years Smalls and his wife, Elizabeth, had been supporting Blevins and the children. After hearing the evidence, the district court judge remanded the three boys to the custody of their father. Blevins and Smalls spent the next two years litigating a property dispute in civil court.

Summary of Proceedings:
Samuel Carr petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his two young sons, Harry and Herbert Carr, from William and Nina Helms, which was granted. A few years earlier, Samuel had placed the boys in the Home for the Friendless in Lincoln, Nebraska, from which institution the Helmses obtained custody of the two. The Helmses did not formally adopt Harry and Herbert, whom they put to work in their traveling minstrel show. After hearing the evidence, Harry and Herbert were released back into the custody of the Home for the Friendless. The judge ordered that Samuel could retrieve his children once he demonstrated that he could properly care for them and after he paid off his debt to the state. 

For background on this case, see the 15 and 16 November 1906 issues of the Hastings Daily Republican. https://www.newspapers.com/clip/97397389/samuel-l-carrs-habeas-corpus-petition/

Summary of Proceedings: J. H. Rosseter sued C. W. Zaueker for the recovery of a few hundred dollars in the Recorder's Court for the City of Salem, Oregon. The city recorder ordered the arrest of Zaueker and set bail at $240. Zaueker petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in the Marion County Circuit Court claiming that his detention was illegal, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Zaueker was released and Rosseter ordered to pay his fees.

["Giller, William M."](hc.pers.002254)|petitioner attorney|[In the Matter of the Application of Frank Kadlec for a Writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0936)
Summary of Proceedings: Frank Kadlec’s roommate, James Kasper, picked up a pair of glasses belonging to Kadlec. In retaliation, Kadlec took Kasper's watch and told him that he would not return it until he got his glasses back. Kasper then filed a complaint claiming Kadlec had committed grand larceny for taking the watch. Kadlec was described as being a “foreigner, unable to read or write the English language readily” and therefore did not have a good understanding of the law. He was the sole provider for his wife and 5 kids and during his incarceration one his sons died and his family is experiencing starvation and poverty. For these reasons, he wanted to be released from jail. The judge approved his writ and Kadlec was called to have his case tried in court.

Repository: Washington State Archives, Puget Sound Regional Branch (Bellevue, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Lee Kee, is arrested on the conviction of keeping a resort for using opium, and sentenced to hard labor for 30 days, as well as a fine of $50. Harold Preston, attorney on behalf of Kee, petitions that he is illegally imprisoned and that he is not guilty of a "crime for which the said Lee Kee should be restrained of his liberty" and that the court that issues the order had "no jurisdiction."

["Tuttle, Samuel J."](hc.pers.001246)|judge|[In the Matter of the Application of Daniel Doody for a writ of Habeas Corpus](hc.case.ne.0580)
Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: Daniel Doodey petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that he was being unlawfully deprived of his liberty by Sheriff Trompen after he was judged insane by a commission the day previous. Judge Tuttle granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Tuttle allowed the writ and ordered that Doodey be released from custody. The next day, Doodey filed for divorce from his wife, Mary Ann Doodey, claiming that she gave false testimony that resulted in him being institutionalized in an insane asylum. The Judge granted the divorce, but sided with Mary Ann and granted her custody of their children.
